entry.title: 丹麦语 DU 3.3 7 Arbejdspladskultur (1)
entry.content:
有趣的表达：

tisse i bukserne for at holde varmen 直译：在裤子里撒尿来保持温暖 意译：饮鸩止渴

Johanna, Manu og Anya

skilte -r, -de, -t 吹嘘，炫耀，张贴

pinlig -t, -e 尴尬的

omvendt -, -e 相反

eks. I Indien er det lige omvendt.

titel titlen, titler, titlerne 头衔

hierarki -et, -er, -erne 层次结构；阶层

almindelig -t, -e 常见的，普通的

tvivl -en 怀疑

  • tvivl om at + SÆTNING/NOGET/hv+SÆTNING
  • komme i tvivl

forventning -en, -er, -erne 期望

overholde -r, …holdt, …holdt 遵守

erklæring -en, -er, -erne 声明 = Erklärung

er vant til = vænne sig til 习惯于

egentlig -t, -e 实际上 = eigentlich

rar -t -e 好的，美丽的

Spørgende ledsætninger

Hv-Spørgsmål:

  • Hvem er han?

    Jeg ved ikke, hvem han er.

  • Hvor arbejder han?

    Jeg ved ikke, hvor han arbejder.

  • Hvem leder arbejdet?

    Jeg ved ikke, hvem der leder arbejdet.

  • Hvem betaler?

    Jeg ved ikke, hvem der betaler.

  • Hvilken bluse er pænest?

    Jeg ved ikke, hvilken bluse der er pænest.

⚠️如果问句中动词后面没有主语（对主语进行提问），则关系从句关系代词之后必须加 der。

Ja/nej-Spørgsmål:

  • Har hun arbejde?

    Jeg ved ikke, om hun har arbejde.

Abdul og chefrollen

bygge -r, -de, -t 建造

leder -en, -e, -ne 领导

Han følger derfor nøje med i alt og styrer alle detaljer. 因此，他密切关注一切，管理好每一个细节。

fordele -r, fordelte, fordelt 分配

instruks -en, -er, -erne 指令，指示

udføre -r, udførte, udført 执行

dygtig -t, -e 精通的

behagelig 愉快的，满足的

Fordele og ulemper ved fladt hierarki

fordele og ulemper 优缺点

at vurdere 评价

Jeg synes, det er …

  • vigtigt
  • rigtigt
  • nødvendigt
  • lige meget
  • interessant
  • problematisk
  • forkert
  • udfordrende 具有挑战性的
  • mærkeligt
  • overraskende
  • tåbeligt 愚蠢的
  • rart/dejligt

at begrunde 理由

for

fordi

at uddybe 详细说明

For eksempel + sætning

entry.title: Fair AI/ML 3 PROP Fair Clustering Revisited
entry.content:
Read the paper Proportionally Fair Clustering Revisited by Micha et Shah.

kkk cluster centers must be placed given nnn points in a metric space.

The cost to each point is its distance to the nearest cluster center.

This paper: Focus on the case where cluster centers can be placed anywhere in metric space.

E.g. L2L^2L2 distance over Rt\mathbb R^tRt, the approximation ratio of greedy capture improves to 222.

For L1,L∞L^1,L^\inftyL1,L∞ metric, the approximation ratio remains 1+21+\sqrt 21+2​.

The paper gives universal lower bounds which apply to all algorithms.

Introduction

Points N\mathcal NN, possible cluster centers M\mathcal MM.

Given k∈Nk\in\mathbb Nk∈N, task is to select a set X⊆MX\subseteq\mathcal MX⊆M consisting of ∣X∣=k|X|=k∣X∣=k cluster centers.

Group fairness.

Proportional fairness.

Contribution

Focus on the case where the metric consists of usual distance functions such as L1,L2,L∞L^1,L^2,L^\inftyL1,L2,L∞ over Rt\mathbb R^tRt.

⚠️Cluster centers can be placed anywhere in the infinite metric space. M=Rt\mathcal M=\mathbb R^tM=Rt❗

请注意此处，候选聚类中心和上一篇论文不一样，所以得出的近似下界不一样。

Greedy Capture by Chen et al. where d∈{L1,L2,L∞}d\in\{L^1,L^2,L^\infty\}d∈{L1,L2,L∞} and M=Rt\mathcal M=\mathbb R^tM=Rt.

For d=L2,M=Rtd=L^2,\mathcal M=\mathbb R^td=L2,M=Rt, GC provides 222-PROP. The approximation is obtained by Apollonius radius.

For L1,L∞L^1,L^\inftyL1,L∞, the approximation ratio can not be better than 1+21+\sqrt21+2​.

Universal lower bounds: for d=L2d=L^2d=L2 and M=Rt\mathcal M=\mathbb R^tM=Rt, no algorithm achieves better than 23≈1.155\frac{2}{\sqrt 3}\approx1.1553​2​≈1.155-PROP, whereas for d∈{L1,L∞}d\in\{L^1,L^\infty\}d∈{L1,L∞} and M=Rt\mathcal M=\mathbb R^tM=Rt, the lower bound is 1.41.41.4.

Also, this paper consider the case where M\mathcal MM is the set of nodes of an unweighted graph, and ddd measures the shortest distance between two nodes on the graph.

  • If the graph is a tree, then PROP must exist. And there are an efficient algorithm.
  • If the graph is arbitrary, k≥n/2k\ge n/2k≥n/2. PROP must exist and can be computed efficiently.
  • Open problem: Whether an exact PROP exists for all graphs.

For d=L2d=L^2d=L2 and M=Rt\mathcal M=\mathbb R^tM=Rt for t≥2t\ge2t≥2, checking whether a clustering is PROP is NP-hard.

When ttt is large,even greedy capture is NP-hard. When ttt is constant, the problem becomes efficiently solvable.

When ttt is large, using a PTASPTASPTAS as sub-routine of greedy capture, we can efficiently compute 2(1+ϵ)2(1+\epsilon)2(1+ϵ)-PROP fair clustering for any fixed ϵ>0\epsilon\gt0ϵ>0

Problem of generalization: Would a clustering that is PROP w.r.t. samples drawn from N\mathcal NN remain approximately PROP w.r.t. entire set N\mathcal NN? Chen et al. proved that the answer is yes when ∣M∣|\mathcal M|∣M∣ is finite. Using the VC dimension, the answer is also yes for M=Rt\mathcal M=\mathbb R^tM=Rt.

Preliminaries

N\mathcal NN: the set of nnn data points lie in a metric space (X,d)(\mathcal X,d)(X,d), where d:X×X→Rd:\mathcal X\times\mathcal X\to\mathbb Rd:X×X→R is a distance function satisfying the triangle inequality.

Consider X=Rt\mathcal X=\mathbb R^tX=Rt for t∈Nt\in\mathbb Nt∈N.

Distance function: L2,L1,L∞L^2,L^1,L^\inftyL2,L1,L∞.

M\mathcal MM: set of candidate cluster centers. In this paper M=X\mathcal M=\mathcal XM=X.

Given k∈Nk\in\mathbb Nk∈N, a kkk-clustering is a set X∈MkX\in\mathcal M^kX∈Mk.

Each x∈Xx\in Xx∈X is called the open cluster center.

Cost to agent i∈Ni\in\mathcal Ni∈N induced by a cluster center x∈Mx\in\mathcal Mx∈M is the distance d(i,x)d(i,x)d(i,x). The cost to agent iii should be the minimal distance.

d(i,X)=min⁡x∈Xd(i,x)d(i,X)=\min_{x\in X}d(i,x)d(i,X)=x∈Xmin​d(i,x)

Agent iii is interested in minimizing the cost.

A set of points S⊆NS\subseteq NS⊆N containing at least ⌈n/k⌉\lceil n/k\rceil⌈n/k⌉, if they can find a new cluster that is better for each of them, it is a violation of fairness (block coalition)

📖Definition 1. ρ\rhoρ-PROP, block coalition. Omitted.

PROP on graphs: given an undirected graph G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E), N⊆V,M=V\mathcal N\subseteq V,\mathcal M=VN⊆V,M=V. Distance between u,v∈Vu,v\in Vu,v∈V is the length of the shortest path.

Greedy Capture

Detail is omitted here.

(1+2)(1+\sqrt2)(1+2​)-PROP

This paper gives a refined analysis of Greedy Capture.

📖Definition 2 (Apollonius radius) Given ρ≥1\rho\ge1ρ≥1, the ρ\rhoρ-Apollonius radius of a metric (X,d)(\mathcal X,d)(X,d) is defined as AX,d(ρ)=sup⁡x,y∈XΔ(ρ,x,y)/d(x,y)A_{\mathcal X,d}(\rho)=\sup_{x,y\in\mathcal X}\Delta(\rho,x,y)/d(x,y)AX,d​(ρ)=supx,y∈X​Δ(ρ,x,y)/d(x,y), where Δ(ρ,x,y)\Delta(\rho,x,y)Δ(ρ,x,y) is the radius of the smallest ball centered at some point in X\mathcal XX that contains the entire set {p∈X:ρ⋅d(p,y)≤d(p,x)}\{p\in\mathcal X:\rho\cdot d(p,y)\le d(p,x)\}{p∈X:ρ⋅d(p,y)≤d(p,x)}.

When ρ>1\rho\gt1ρ>1, the set is a ball.

🎯Theorem 3. For any metric (X,d)(\mathcal X,d)(X,d) and M=X\mathcal M=\mathcal XM=X, greedy capture finds a ρ\rhoρ-PROP clustering, where ρ≥1\rho\ge1ρ≥1 is the smallest positive number satisfying AX,d(ρ)⋅ρ+1ρ≤1A_{\mathcal X,d}(\rho)\cdot\frac{\rho+1}{\rho}\le1AX,d​(ρ)⋅ρρ+1​≤1.

M=X\mathcal M=\mathcal XM=X: 候选聚类中心可以是空间上任意一点。

Proof by triangle inequality. Proof that if XXX is not ρ\rhoρ-PROP, then AX,d(ρ)⋅ρ+1ρ>1A_{\mathcal X,d}(\rho)\cdot\frac{\rho+1}{\rho}\gt1AX,d​(ρ)⋅ρρ+1​>1.

🎯Theorem 4. For any metric (X,d)(\mathcal X,d)(X,d), the ρ\rhoρ-Apollonius radius is AX,d(ρ)≤1ρ−1A_{\mathcal X,d}(\rho)\le\frac{1}{\rho-1}AX,d​(ρ)≤ρ−11​. Hence, greedy capture finds a (1+2)(1+\sqrt2)(1+2​)-PROP fair clustering for every metric.

在我看来，本篇论文定义了一个复杂的概念——阿波罗尼乌斯半径，来形式化证明算法结果的下界。

但是这个阿波罗尼乌斯半径的定义过于复杂了。

Next, the paper shows for d=L2d=L^2d=L2, the ρ\rhoρ-Apollonius radius is better, 222-PROP guarantee.

🎯Theorem 5. For the metric space (R2,L2)(\mathbb R^2,L^2)(R2,L2), where t∈Nt\in\mathbb Nt∈N, the ρ\rhoρ-Apollonius radius AR2,L2(ρ)≤ρρ2−1A_{\mathbb R^2,L^2}(\rho)\le\frac{\rho}{\rho^2-1}AR2,L2​(ρ)≤ρ2−1ρ​, and hence, greedy capture finds a 222-PROP clustering.

Proof omitted.

Whether the introduction of Apollonius improves approximation bound for other distance metrics. For L1,L∞L^1,L^\inftyL1,L∞, the answer is unfortunately NO. The approximation remains 1+21+\sqrt 21+2​.

🎯Theorem 6. For the metric space (Rt,d)(\mathbb R^t,d)(Rt,d) where t≥2t\ge2t≥2 and d∈{L1,L∞}d\in\{L^1,L^\infty\}d∈{L1,L∞}, and M=Rt\mathcal M=\mathbb R^tM=Rt, there exists an example in which the clustering produced by greedy capture is not ρ\rhoρ-PROP for ρ<1+2\rho\lt1+\sqrt2ρ<1+2​.

Universal Lower Bounds

This paper generalizes lower bounds on approximation to PROP that apply to ALL ALGORITHMS.

Chen et al. showed that ρ<2\rho<2ρ<2 is not guaranteed. For N=M\mathcal N=\mathcal MN=M, the weaker lower bound 1.51.51.5.

This paper: for the case where M=X=Rt\mathcal M=\mathcal X=\mathbb R^tM=X=Rt and d∈{L1,L2,L∞}d\in\{L^1,L^2,L^\infty\}d∈{L1,L2,L∞}.

再次提醒：M=X\mathcal M=\mathcal XM=X: 候选聚类中心可以是空间上任意一点。

  • When t=1t=1t=1, it’s easy to see that there always exist PROP clusterings.
  • When t≥2t\ge2t≥2, a lower bound 2/32/\sqrt32/3​ for d=L2d=L^2d=L2 and a lower bound 1.41.41.4 for d∈{L1,L∞}d\in\{L^1,L^\infty\}d∈{L1,L∞}.

🎯Theorem 7. For the metric space (Rt,L2)(\mathbb R^t,L^2)(Rt,L2) where t≥2t\ge2t≥2 and M=Rt\mathcal M=\mathbb R^tM=Rt, there is an example in which no clustering is ρ\rhoρ-PROP for p<2/3≈1.155p\lt2/\sqrt3\approx1.155p<2/3​≈1.155.

Closing the gap between lower bound 1.1551.1551.155 and upper bound 222 for L2L^2L2 is an open problem.

🎯Theorem 8. For the metric space (Rt,d)(\mathbb R^t,d)(Rt,d), where t≥2t\ge2t≥2 and d∈{L1,L∞}d\in\{L^1,L^\infty\}d∈{L1,L∞}, and M=Rt\mathcal M=\mathbb R^tM=Rt, there is an example in which no clustering is ρ\rhoρ-PROP for ρ<1.4\rho\lt1.4ρ<1.4.

Clustering in Graphs

In this section, we consider the special case where the metric space (X,d)(\mathcal X,d)(X,d) is induced by an undirected graph G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E).

Consider the case of M=X=V\mathcal M=\mathcal X=VM=X=V. Distance d(x,y)d(x,y)d(x,y) is the length of the shortest path between x,yx,yx,y.

所有节点都是候选聚类中心，距离定义为最短路长度。

When GGG is a tree, an exact PROP clustering always exists, and can be computed by an efficient algorithm.

PROP Clustering for Trees

First root the tree at an arbitrary node rrr to obtain a rooted tree (G,r)(G,r)(G,r).

Denote with hhh the height of the rooted rooted tree, and with level(x)level(x)level(x) the height of node xxx relative to root rrr with level(r)=1level(r)=1level(r)=1.

Let ST(x)ST(x)ST(x) denote the sub-tree of node xxx

The algorithm starts from the leaves, opens a center every time it finds a node whose sub-tree contains at least ⌈n/k⌉\lceil n/k\rceil⌈n/k⌉ nodes, then deletes this sub-tree from the graph. At the end, the cost to each node is still defined using the closest node at which a center is opened by the algorithm.

Pseudo Code - PROP Clustering for Trees

  1. Root the tree GGG at an arbitrary node rrr.
  2. X←∅X\gets\emptyX←∅
  3. Gd←GG^d\gets GGd←G.
  4. for ℓ=d\ell=dℓ=d to 111 do
    1. Gℓ−1=GℓG^{\ell-1}=G^\ellGℓ−1=Gℓ
    2. for every x∈Vx\in Vx∈V with level(x)=llevel(x)=llevel(x)=l and ∣ST(x)∣≥⌈n/k⌉|ST(x)|\ge\lceil n/k\rceil∣ST(x)∣≥⌈n/k⌉ do
      • X←X∪{x}X\gets X\cup\{x\}X←X∪{x}
      • Gℓ−1←Gℓ−1╲ST(x)G^{\ell-1}\gets G^{\ell-1}\diagdown ST(x)Gℓ−1←Gℓ−1╲ST(x)
  5. if G0≠∅G^0\neq\emptyG0=∅ then X←X∪{r}X\gets X\cup\{r\}X←X∪{r}
  6. return XXX

🎯Theorem 9. Let G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E) be an undirected tree, (V,d)(V,d)(V,d) be the metric induced by GGG, N⊆V,M=V\mathcal N\subseteq V,\mathcal M=VN⊆V,M=V, and k∈Nk\in\mathbb Nk∈N. Then, the algorithm yields a PROP clustering.

Hard proof by contradiction.

What about Non-tree

Consider the universal lower bound for (R2,L1)(\mathbb R^2,L^1)(R2,L1) metric from Theorem 8.

If the graph is dense enough, we can derive same lower bound of 1.41.41.4.

❓Whether better lower bounds exist is an open problem.

❓For special case where N=V\mathcal N=VN=V, we do not know whether PROP always exists

If GGG is connected and we want to place a large number of clusters k≥n/2k\ge n/2k≥n/2, then PROP always exists. This is because a dominating set of any size k≥n/2k\ge n/2k≥n/2 is guaranteed to exist in a graph with nnn nodes and can be computed efficiently.

Definition of dominating set: A set of nodes is called a dominating set if every node in the graph is either in this set or adjacent to a node in this set.

Thus the problem of finding a PROP clustering in general graphs with N=M=V\mathcal N=\mathcal M=VN=M=V is trivial when k≥n/2k\ge n/2k≥n/2, but remains open when k<n/2k\lt n/2k<n/2.

Computational Aspects

Two problems:

  1. Checking whether a PROP clustering exits.
  2. Implementing the Greedy Capture when M=Rt\mathcal M=\mathbb R^tM=Rt.

🎯Theorem 10, Given a finite N\mathcal NN, finite M\mathcal MM, k∈Nk\in\mathbb Nk∈N, and d=L2d=L^2d=L2, checking whether a PROP clustering exists is NP-hard.

Polynomial-time reduction from the planar monotone rectilinear 3-SAT problem.

Planar monotone rectilinear 3-SAT problem: Given a 3-SAT formula, each clause cjc_jcj​ consists of only positive or only negative literals, the graph connecting clauses to literals they contain is planar, and this graph has a planar embedding in which each variable viv_ivi​ is represented by a rectangle on the xxx-axis and each positive/negative clause is represented by a rectangle above/below xxx-axis with 3 vertical lines or legs to its 3 variables.

什么玩意啊，什么乱七八糟的 NP-hard 问题。欺负我不会证规约是吧。

🎯Theorem 11. Let t∈Nt\in\mathbb Nt∈N, finite N⊂Rt\mathcal N\subset\mathbb R^tN⊂Rt, and k∈Nk\in\mathbb Nk∈N be given as input. Suppose M=Rt\mathcal M=\mathbb R^tM=Rt and d=L2d=L^2d=L2. Then, the following hold:

  1. The clustering returned by Greedy Capture algorithm cannot be computed in polynomial time unless P=NPP=NPP=NP.
  2. If ttt is constant, then it can be computed in polynomial time.
  3. Even if ttt is not constant, for any constant ϵ>0\epsilon>0ϵ>0, there exists a polynomial time algorithm which finds a (2+ϵ)(2+\epsilon)(2+ϵ)-PROP clustering.

Learning Fair Clustering by Sampling

VERY DIFFICULT!

Is a clustering that is approximately PROP w.r.t. random samples taken from an underlying population would remain approximately PROP w.r.t. the whole population.

YES!

📖Definition 12. We say that a kkk-clustering XXX is ρ\rhoρ-PROP fair to (1+ϵ)(1+\epsilon)(1+ϵ)-deviations w.r.t. N\mathcal NN if for all S⊆NS\subseteq\mathcal NS⊆N with ∣S∣≥∣N∣⋅(1+ϵ)/k|S|\ge|\mathcal N|\cdot(1+\epsilon)/k∣S∣≥∣N∣⋅(1+ϵ)/k and all y∈My\in\mathcal My∈M, there exists at least one i∈Si\in Si∈S s.t. ρ⋅d(i,y)≥d(i,X)\rho\cdot d(i,y)\ge d(i,X)ρ⋅d(i,y)≥d(i,X).

📖Definition 13. Given a set of points N\mathcal NN, a kkk-clustering XXX, and y∈My\in\mathcal My∈M, define the binary classifier hX,y:N→{0,1}h_{X,y}:\mathcal N\to\{0,1\}hX,y​:N→{0,1} s.t. hX,y(i)=1h_{X,y}(i)=1hX,y​(i)=1 iff ρ⋅d(i,y)<d(i,X)\rho\cdot d(i,y)\lt d(i,X)ρ⋅d(i,y)<d(i,X). Define the error of this classifier on a set of points S⊆NS\subseteq\mathcal NS⊆N as errS(hX,y)=(1/∣S∣)⋅∑i∈ShX,y(i)err_S(h_{X,y})=(1/|S|)\cdot\sum_{i\in S}h_{X,y}(i)errS​(hX,y​)=(1/∣S∣)⋅∑i∈S​hX,y​(i).

The classifier equals 111 iff iii can be part of a coalition that complains about the unfairness of XXX by demonstrating yyy as a location that provides them ρ\rhoρ-improvement.

XXX is ρ\rhoρ-PROP to (1+ϵ)(1+\epsilon)(1+ϵ)-deviations w.r.t. N\mathcal NN iff errN(X,y)≤1+ϵkerr_\mathcal N(X,y)\le\frac{1+\epsilon}{k}errN​(X,y)≤k1+ϵ​ for all y∈My\in\mathcal My∈M.

Goal: Show that given a large enough random simple N⊆NN\subseteq\mathcal NN⊆N, if we have clustering XXX that is ρ\rhoρ-PROP w.r.t. NNN, then it is ρ\rhoρ-PROP to (1+ϵ)(1+\epsilon)(1+ϵ)-deviations w.r.t. N\mathcal NN with high probability. But there is no control over X,yX,yX,y. Because of the uniform convergence guarantee.

∣errN(hX,y)−errN(hX,y)∣|err_N(h_{X,y})-err_\mathcal N(h_{X,y})|∣errN​(hX,y​)−errN​(hX,y​)∣ is bounded for all X,yX,yX,y.

📖Definition 14 (VC Dimension). Let N\mathcal NN be a set of points. Let H\mathcal HH be a family of binary classifier over N\mathcal NN. We say that H\mathcal HH shatters S⊆NS\subseteq\mathcal NS⊆N if for every labeling ℓ:S→{0,1}\ell:S\to\{0,1\}ℓ:S→{0,1}, there exists a classifier h∈Hh\in\mathcal Hh∈H s.t. h(i)=ℓ(i)h(i)=\ell(i)h(i)=ℓ(i) for all i∈Si\in Si∈S. The VC dimension of H\mathcal HH, denoted dimVC(H)dim^{VC}(\mathcal H)dimVC(H), is the size of the largest SSS that can be shattered by H\mathcal HH.

🤔Proposition 15. Let H\mathcal HH be a family of binary classifier over a set of points N\mathcal NN. If N⊆NN\subseteq NN⊆N is a uniformly random sample with ∣N∣≥Ω(dimVC(H)+ln⁡(1/δ)ϵ2)|N|\ge\Omega\left(\frac{dim^{VC}(\mathcal H)+\ln(1/\delta)}{\epsilon^2}\right)∣N∣≥Ω(ϵ2dimVC(H)+ln(1/δ)​), then with probability at least 1−δ1-\delta1−δ, ∣errN(h)−errN(h)∣≤ϵ|err_N(h)-err_\mathcal N(h)|\le\epsilon∣errN​(h)−errN​(h)∣≤ϵ for all h∈Hh\in\mathcal Hh∈H.

🎯Theorem 16. Fix ϵ,δ>0,ρ≥1,k,t∈N\epsilon,\delta\gt0,\rho\ge1,k,t\in\Nϵ,δ>0,ρ≥1,k,t∈N, and metric (X,d)(\mathcal X,d)(X,d) where X=Rt\mathcal X=\R^tX=Rt and d=L2d=L^2d=L2. Let N\mathcal NN be a set of points and M=Rt\mathcal M=\R^tM=Rt be the set of candidate centers. Let N⊆NN\subseteq\mathcal NN⊆N be sampled uniformly at random with ∣N∣≥Ω(k2⋅(tkln⁡k+ln⁡(1/δ))ϵ2)|N|\ge\Omega\left(\frac{k^2\cdot(tk\ln k+\ln(1/\delta))}{\epsilon^2}\right)∣N∣≥Ω(ϵ2k2⋅(tklnk+ln(1/δ))​). Then with probability at least 1−δ1-\delta1−δ, every kkk-clustering X∈MkX\in\mathcal M^kX∈Mk that is ρ\rhoρ-PROP w.r.t. NNN is ρ\rhoρ-PROP to (1+ϵ)(1+\epsilon)(1+ϵ)-deviation w.r.t. N\mathcal NN.

Open Questions

This paper mainly consider M\mathcal MM is entire metric space.

There are some open questions.

Bridging Gaps

Can we bridge the lower (1+2)(1+\sqrt2)(1+2​) and upper bounds on the approximation ratio to PROP.

Conjecture for L2L^2L2, the lower bound 2/32/\sqrt32/3​ may be achievable.

Maybe by Jung’s theorem, for L2L^2L2 distance in R2\R^2R2, any set of points with diameter at most 111 is contained in a ball of radius at most 1/31/\sqrt31/3​. This could be useful in closing the gap for L2L^2L2.

On Graphs

Does PROP clustering always exist for all graphs when N=M\mathcal N=\mathcal MN=M is the set of all nodes of the graph?

Computational Hardness

What is the computational hardness for other distance metrics?

Other ML Models

Can we adapt this PROP to other machine learning settings such as regression or classification?

Some Personal Unremarkable Rants

This paper revisit Greedy Capture. But remember M=\mathcal M=M= whole metric space, this gives different bounds.

Some dazzling new concepts like “Apollonius radius”, “shatter” etc.

Impressive spectacular showmanship on hardness proof.
entry.summary: Read the paper

entry.title: Fair AI/ML 2 PROP Fair Clustering
entry.content:
Read the paper Proportionally Fair Clustering by Chen et al.

Abstract

nnn points, kkk centers.

Proportionality: any n/kn/kn/k points are entitled to form own cluster if there is another center that is closer in distance for all n/kn/kn/k points.

Clustering with no justified complaints from any subset of agents.

Tradeoff between proportional solutions and kkk-means objective.

Introduction

In centroid clustering, we want to partition data into kkk clusters by choosing kkk centers and then matching points to one of the centers.

Each data point represents a individual. We with the clustering to be fair. These agents prefer to be clustered accurately.

A clustering is fair if it respects the entitlements of groups of agents: a subset of agents is entitled to choose a center for themselves if they constitute a sufficiently large fraction of the population w.r.t. the total number of clusters. No priori knowledge about which points should be protected.

Preliminaries

N\mathcal NN data points, ∣N∣=n|\mathcal N|=n∣N∣=n.

M\mathcal MM feasible cluster centers, ∣M∣=m|\mathcal M|=m∣M∣=m.

For i,j∈M∪Ni,j\in\mathcal M\cup\mathcal Ni,j∈M∪N, we have distance (i,j)(i,j)(i,j) satisfying the triangle inequality.

Open a set X⊆MX\subseteq\mathcal MX⊆M of ∣X∣=k|X|=k∣X∣=k centers, and then match all points in N\mathcal NN to the closest center in XXX.

For a particular solution XXX and agent i∈Ni\in\mathcal Ni∈N, let Di(X)=min⁡x∈Xd(i,x)D_i(X)=\min_{x\in X}d(i,x)Di​(X)=minx∈X​d(i,x). A good clustering solution XXX will have small values of Di(X)D_i(X)Di​(X).

Different measures, different objectives:

  • kkk-median: ∑i∈NDi(X)\sum_{i\in\mathcal N}D_i(X)∑i∈N​Di​(X)
  • kkk-means: ∑i∈N(Di(X))2\sum_{i\in\mathcal N}(D_i(X))^2∑i∈N​(Di​(X))2
  • kkk-center: max⁡i∈NDi(X)\max_{i\in\mathcal N}D_i(X)maxi∈N​Di​(X)

Individuals prefer to be closer to their center in terms of distance.

📖Definition 1. Let X⊆MX\subseteq\mathcal MX⊆M with ∣X∣=k|X|=k∣X∣=k. S⊆NS\subseteq NS⊆N is a blocking coalition against XXX if ∣S∣≥⌈nk⌉|S|\ge\lceil\frac{n}{k}\rceil∣S∣≥⌈kn​⌉ and ∃y∈M\exist y\in\mathcal M∃y∈M s.t. ∀i∈S,d(i,y)<Di(X)\forall i\in S,d(i,y)\lt D_i(X)∀i∈S,d(i,y)<Di​(X). X⊆NX\subseteq \mathcal NX⊆N is proportional if there is no blocking coalition against XXX.

阻塞联盟：存在一个候选中心点 yyy，存在一组数据点 SSS 满足其点数要比簇平均点数多：使得 SSS 中任意一点到 yyy 的距离，都比这组数据点到原来分配的对应簇中心点的距离近。

比例公平：一组簇分配中不包含阻塞联盟，则该簇分配是比例公平的。

Equivalently, XXX is proportional if ∀S⊆N\forall S \subseteq N∀S⊆N with ∣S∣≥⌈nk⌉|S| \ge\lceil\frac{n}{k}\rceil∣S∣≥⌈kn​⌉ and for all y∈My \in My∈M, there exists i∈Si \in Si∈S with d(i,y)≥Di(X)d(i, y) \ge D_i(X)d(i,y)≥Di​(X).

❗The quantification is over all subset of sufficient size. Do not consider a single i∈Si\in Si∈S and ignore all of the other points.

Advantages of PROP

  • PROP implies weak Pareto optimality: For any PROP solution XXX, there does not exist another solution X′X'X′ s.t. Di(X′)<Di(X)D_i(X')\lt D_i(X)Di​(X′)<Di​(X) for all i∈Ni\in\mathcal Ni∈N.
  • Oblivious, does not depend on sensitive attribute or protected sub-groups.
  • Robust to outlier.
  • Scale invariant: a multiplicative scaling of all distances does not affect the set of PROP solution.
  • Approximately PROP can be efficiently computed.
  • Can be efficiently checked: no need to compute entire pairwise distance matrix.

However, PROP is incompatible with kkk-center, kkk-means, kkk-median in the worst case.

📖Definition 2. X⊆MX\subseteq\mathcal MX⊆M with ∣X∣=k|X|=k∣X∣=k is ρ\rhoρ-approximate proportional (abbr. ρ\rhoρ-proportional) if ∀S⊆N\forall S\subseteq\mathcal N∀S⊆N with ∣S∣>⌈nk⌉|S|\gt\lceil\frac{n}{k}\rceil∣S∣>⌈kn​⌉ and ∀y∈M\forall y\in\mathcal M∀y∈M, there exists i∈Si\in Si∈S with ρ⋅d(i,y)≥Di(X)\rho\cdot d(i,y)\ge D_i(X)ρ⋅d(i,y)≥Di​(X).

Results and Outline

Existence of PROP and its approximation

PROP clustering solution doesn’t always exist.

  • Better than 222-PROP solution doesn’t always exist.

A greedy algorithm yields (1+2)(1+\sqrt2)(1+2​)-PROP solution in the worst case.

PROP as constraint

To optimize kkk-median objective subject to PROP constraint.

Use the rounding to find an O(1)O(1)O(1)-PROP solution to the kkk-median.

PROP and Randomness

PROP is approximately preserved if we take a random sample of the data points of size O~(k3)\tilde{O}(k^3)O~(k3).

For constant kkk, we can check if a given clustering s proportional as well as compute approximately PROP solutions in near linear time, comparable to the time for classic kkk-means heuristic.

Existence and Computation of PROP Solutions

🤔Claim 1. For all ρ<2\rho\lt2ρ<2, a ρ\rhoρ-PROP solution is not guaranteed to exist.

Consider instance N={ai},M={xi}\mathcal N=\{a_i\},\mathcal M=\{x_i\}N={ai​},M={xi​} with ∣N∣=∣M∣=6,k=3|\mathcal N|=|\mathcal M|=6,k=3∣N∣=∣M∣=6,k=3 with distance:

x1x2x3x4x5x6
a1412∞∞∞
a2241∞∞∞
a3124∞∞∞
a4∞∞∞412
a5∞∞∞241
a6∞∞∞124

It’s easy to check that any solution can not be better than 222-PROP.

🤔Claim 2. In case where N=M\mathcal N=\mathcal MN=M, for all ρ<1.5\rho\lt1.5ρ<1.5, a ρ\rhoρ-PROP solution is not guaranteed to exist.

A counterexample in the paper.

Computing 2.414-PROP Clustering

Let B(x,δ)={i∈N:d(i,x)≤δ}B(x,\delta)=\{i\in\mathcal N:d(i,x)\le\delta\}B(x,δ)={i∈N:d(i,x)≤δ} (The ball of distance δ\deltaδ about center xxx).

Pseudo Code - Greedy Capture

  1. δ←0,X←∅,N←N\delta\gets0,X\gets\empty,N\gets\mathcal Nδ←0,X←∅,N←N
  2. while N≠∅N\neq\emptyN=∅, do
    • Smoothly increase δ\deltaδ
    • while ∃x∈X\exist x\in X∃x∈X s.t. ∣B(x,δ)∩N∣≥1|B(x,\delta)\cap N|\ge1∣B(x,δ)∩N∣≥1 do
      • N←N╲B(x,δ)N\gets N\diagdown B(x,\delta)N←N╲B(x,δ).
    • while ∃x∈(M╲X)\exist x\in(\mathcal M\diagdown X)∃x∈(M╲X) s.t. ∣B(x,δ)∩N∣≥⌈nk⌉|B(x,\delta)\cap N|\ge\lceil\frac{n}{k}\rceil∣B(x,δ)∩N∣≥⌈kn​⌉ do
      • X←X∪{x}X\gets X\cup\{x\}X←X∪{x}
      • N←N╲B(x,δ)N\gets N\diagdown B(x,\delta)N←N╲B(x,δ)
  3. return XXX

Greedy Capture runs in O~(mn)\tilde O(mn)O~(mn) time.

The algorithm continuously grows. When the ball around a center has captured ⌈nk⌉\lceil\frac{n}{k}\rceil⌈kn​⌉ points, we open that center and disregards all of the captured points.

Difference between kkk-means and kkk-median: Balls grow around data points in kkk-median instead of centers.

🎯Theorem 1. Greedy Capture algorithm yields a (1+2)(1+\sqrt2)(1+2​)-PROP clustering, and there exists an instance for which this bound is tight.

  1. XXX uses at most kkk centers, because it only opens a center when ⌈nk⌉\lceil\frac{n}{k}\rceil⌈kn​⌉ unmatched points are absorbed by the sphere. This can only happen at most kkk times.
  2. Suppose for contradiction that XXX is not (1+2)(1+\sqrt 2)(1+2​)-PROP. …

The example where Greedy Capture yields exactly this bound: N={a1,⋯ ,a6},M={x1,⋯ ,x4},k=3\mathcal N=\{a_1,\cdots,a_6\},\mathcal M=\{x_1,\cdots,x_4\},k=3N={a1​,⋯,a6​},M={x1​,⋯,x4​},k=3.

x1x2x3x4
a111+√2∞∞
a2√2-11-ε∞∞
a31+√21-ε∞∞
a4∞∞11+√2
a5∞∞√2-11-ε
a6∞∞1+√21-ε
  • Greedy Capture will open x2x_2x2​ and x4x_4x4​. The coalition {a1,a2}\{a_1,a_2\}{a1​,a2​} can each reduce their distance by factor 1+21+\sqrt21+2​ and ϵ→0\epsilon\to0ϵ→0 by deviating to x1x_1x1​.

I strongly suspect that the PROP fairness notion in clustering is thought after the algorithm.🤐

❓Open Problem: Can we fill the gap between 1+21+\sqrt 21+2​ and 222 by inventing new algorithm? Or can we invent a new algorithm that has a better bound than 1+21+\sqrt21+2​?

Local Capture Heuristic

Local Capture heuristic produces more proportional clustering.

It takes a target value of ρ\rhoρ as a parameter, and proceeds by iteratively finding a center that violates ρ\rhoρ-fairness and swapping it for the center in the current solution that is least demanded.

Pseudo Code - LCH

Input: ρ\rhoρ

  1. Initialize XXX as a random subset of kkk centers from M\mathcal MM.
  2. repeat until no changes occur:
    1. for y∈My\in\mathcal My∈M do
      • Sy←{i∈N:ρ⋅diy<Di(X)}S_y\gets\{i\in N:\rho\cdot d_{iy}\lt D_i(X)\}Sy​←{i∈N:ρ⋅diy​<Di​(X)}
      • if ∣Sy∣≥⌈nk⌉|S_y|\ge\lceil\frac{n}{k}\rceil∣Sy​∣≥⌈kn​⌉ then
        • x∗←arg⁡min⁡x∈X∣{i∈N:dix=Di(X)}∣x^*\gets\arg\min_{x\in X}|\{i\in N:d_{ix}=D_i(X)\}|x∗←argminx∈X​∣{i∈N:dix​=Di​(X)}∣
        • X←(X╲{x∗})∪{y}X\gets(X\diagdown\{x^*\})\cup\{y\}X←(X╲{x∗})∪{y}
  3. return XXX

LCH runs in O~(mn2)\tilde O(mn^2)O~(mn2) time. No guarantee of convergence! aka for a given ρ\rhoρ, there may not exist a ρ\rhoρ-proportional solution.

If LCH terminate, it must return a ρ\rhoρ-PROP solution.

PROP as a Constraint

Problem with LCH and Greedy Capture: They may find a PROP clustering with poor global objective, even when exact PROP clustering with good global objectives exist.

A bad example: k=2k=2k=2, two easily defined clusters containing 40%,60%40\%,60\%40%,60% of the data points respectively. It is possible Greedy Capture only open one point in the larger cluster. It is PROP, but not optimized w.r.t. main object.

So we need to solve this problem by optimizing the kkk-median objective subject to PROP as a constraint.

Consider kkk-median and kkk-means.

🎯Theorem 2. There is a ρ\rhoρ-PROP clustering with kkk-median objective ccc. In polynomial time in mmm and nnn, we can compute a O(ρ)O(\rho)O(ρ)-PROP clustering with kkk-median objective at most 8c8c8c.

We can compute a constant approximate PROP with kkk-median objective at most eight times the minimum kkk-median objective PROP clustering.

Linear Programming

The standard linear programming relaxation of the kkk-median minimization problem. Then add a constraint to encode PROP.

Minimize ∑i∈N∑j∈Md(i,j)zij  (1)Subject to ∑j∈Mzij=1∀i∈N  (2)zij≤yj∀j∈M,∀i∈N  (3)∑j∈Myj≤k  (4)∑j′∈B(j,γRj)yj′≥1∀j∈M  (5)zij,yj∈[0,1]∀j∈M,∀i∈N  (6)\text{Minimize }\sum_{i\in\mathcal N}\sum_{j\in\mathcal M}d(i,j)z_{ij}\ \ (1)\\\text{Subject to }\sum_{j\in\mathcal M}z_{ij}=1\forall i\in\mathcal N\ \ (2)\\z_{ij}\le y_j\forall j\in\mathcal M,\forall i\in\mathcal N\ \ (3)\\\sum_{j\in\mathcal M}y_j\le k\ \ (4)\\\sum_{j'\in B(j,\gamma R_j)}y_{j'}\ge1\forall j\in\mathcal M\ \ (5)\\z_{ij},y_j\in[0,1]\forall j\in\mathcal M,\forall i\in\mathcal N\ \ (6)Minimize i∈N∑​j∈M∑​d(i,j)zij​  (1)Subject to j∈M∑​zij​=1∀i∈N  (2)zij​≤yj​∀j∈M,∀i∈N  (3)j∈M∑​yj​≤k  (4)j′∈B(j,γRj​)∑​yj′​≥1∀j∈M  (5)zij​,yj​∈[0,1]∀j∈M,∀i∈N  (6)

B(j,γR)B(j,\gamma R)B(j,γR) is the ball with center jjj with radius γR\gamma RγR.

zijz_{ij}zij​ is the indicator variable equal to 111 if i∈Ni\in\mathcal Ni∈N is matched to j∈Mj\in\mathcal Mj∈M.

yjy_jyj​ is the indicator variable equal to 111 if j∈Xj\in Xj∈X, i.e., if we want to use the center jjj in the clustering.

  • Objective (1) is the kkk-median objective.
  • Constraint (2) requires that every point must be matched.
  • Constraint (3) ensures that every points must be matched to the only center.
  • Constraint (4) allows at most kkk centers to be opened.
  • Constraint (6) relax the indicator to be real value between 000 and 111.

The elaboration of constraint (5): it approximately encodes PROP. Let RjR_jRj​ be the minimum value s.t. ∣B(j,Rj)∣≥⌈nk⌉|B(j,R_j)|\ge\lceil\frac{n}{k}\rceil∣B(j,Rj​)∣≥⌈kn​⌉. aka RjR_jRj​ is the distance of the ⌈nk⌉\lceil\frac{n}{k}\rceil⌈kn​⌉ farthest point in N\mathcal NN from jjj.

🤔Lemma 1. Let XXX be a clustering, γ≥1\gamma\ge1γ≥1. If ∀j∈M\forall j\in \mathcal M∀j∈M there exists some x∈Xx\in Xx∈X s.t. d(j,x)≤γRjd(j,x)\le\gamma R_jd(j,x)≤γRj​, then XXX is (1+γ)(1+\gamma)(1+γ)-PROP. If XXX is γ\gammaγ-PROP, then ∀j∈M\forall j\in \mathcal M∀j∈M there exists some x∈Xx\in Xx∈X s.t. d(j,x)≤(1+γ)Rjd(j,x)\le(1+\gamma)R_jd(j,x)≤(1+γ)Rj​.

Proof by contradiction and triangle inequality.

So ρ\rhoρ-PROP clustering XXX with kkk-median objective ccc. In constraint (5) γ=ρ+1\gamma=\rho+1γ=ρ+1. Lemma 1 guarantees that XXX is feasible for LP.

So the fractional solution has kkk-median objective is at most ccc. Then round the resulting fractional solution. A variation of rounding algorithm preserves constraint (5).

🤔Lemma 2. Let {yj},{zij}\{y_j\},\{z_{ij}\}{yj​},{zij​} be a fractional solution to the linear program in LP. There is an integer solution {y^j},{z^ij}\{\hat y_j\},\{\hat z_{ij}\}{y^​j​},{z^ij​} that is 888-approximation to the objective, and that opens kkk centers. Furthermore, for all j∈Mj\in\mathcal Mj∈M, ∑j′∈B(j,27γRj)y^j′≥1\sum_{j'\in B(j,27\gamma R_j)}\hat y_{j'}\ge1∑j′∈B(j,27γRj​)​y^​j′​≥1.

Lemma 1 + 2 implies result of the rounding (27(1+ρ)+1)(27(1+\rho)+1)(27(1+ρ)+1)-PROP, by setting γ=1+ρ\gamma=1+\rhoγ=1+ρ. Since kkk-median objective of the fractional solution is at most ccc, kkk-median objective of the rounded solution is at most 8c8c8c by proof. The factor 272727 can be improved to 131313 in the special case where N=M\mathcal N=\mathcal MN=M.

Proof of Lemma 2

Argument is to show that with constraint (5), after rounding, the results is still approximately satisfied.

Given a fractional solution to the linear program as {yj},{zij}\{y_j\},\{z_{ij}\}{yj​},{zij​}, let Cˉi=∑j∈Md(i,j)zij\bar C_i=\sum_{j\in\mathcal M}d(i,j)z_{ij}Cˉi​=∑j∈M​d(i,j)zij​ aka contribution of point iii to the kkk-median objective in the fractional optimum.

  • Step 1: Consolidate all demands tit_iti​ (for all points it is set to 111) to obtain {ti′}\{t_i'\}{ti′​} s.t. ∀i,j∈M\forall i,j\in\mathcal M∀i,j∈M with ti′,tj′>0t_i',t_j'\gt0ti′​,tj′​>0, they must be sufficiently far away s.t. cij>4max⁡(Cˉi,Cˉj)c_{ij}\gt4\max(\bar C_i,\bar C_j)cij​>4max(Cˉi​,Cˉj​). Let M′\mathcal M'M′ be the set of centers with positive demand after this step, i.e., M′={j∈M:tj′>0}\mathcal M'=\{j\in\mathcal M:t_j'\gt0\}M′={j∈M:tj′​>0}.
  • Step 2a: Consolidate open centers by moving each center not in M′\mathcal M'M′ to the nearest center in M′\mathcal M'M′.
  • Step 2b: …
  • …

Very complex.

Sampling for Linear-Time Implementations and Auditing

PROP under uniform random sampling.

Draw ∣N∣|N|∣N∣ individuals independent and identically distributed from the uniform distribution on N\mathcal NN.

This paper shows that PROP is well preserved under random sampling.

PROP Under Random Sampling

For any X⊆MX\subseteq\mathcal MX⊆M of size kkk and center y∈My\in\mathcal My∈M, define R(N,X,y)={i∈N:Di(X)>ρ⋅d(i,y)}R(\mathcal N,X,y)=\{i\in\mathcal N:D_i(X)\gt\rho\cdot d(i,y)\}R(N,X,y)={i∈N:Di​(X)>ρ⋅d(i,y)}. Note that XXX is not ρ\rhoρ-PROP w.r.t. N\mathcal NN iff there is some y∈My\in\mathcal My∈M s.t. ∣R(N,X,y)∣∣N∣≥1k\frac{|R(\mathcal N,X,y)|}{|\mathcal N|}\ge\frac{1}{k}∣N∣∣R(N,X,y)∣​≥k1​.

A random sample approximately preserves this fraction for all solution XXX and deviating centers yyy.

Proof sketch: we take a union bound over all possible solutions and deviations, and there are only k⋅Cmkk\cdot C_m^kk⋅Cmk​ such combinations.

🤔🎯Theorem 3. Given N,M\mathcal N,\mathcal MN,M and parameter ρ≥1\rho\ge1ρ≥1, fix parameters ϵ,δ∈[0,1]\epsilon,\delta\in[0,1]ϵ,δ∈[0,1]. Let N⊆NN\subseteq\mathcal NN⊆N of size Ω(k3ϵ2log⁡mδ)\Omega(\frac{k^3}{\epsilon^2}\log\frac{m}{\delta})Ω(ϵ2k3​logδm​) be chosen uniformly at random. Then, with probability at least 1−δ1-\delta1−δ, the following holds for all (X,y)(X,y)(X,y):

∣∣R(N,X,y)∣∣N∣−∣R(N,X,y)∣∣N∣∣≤ϵk\left\vert\frac{\vert R(N,X,y)\vert}{\vert N\vert}-\frac{\vert R(\mathcal N,X,y)\vert}{\vert\mathcal N\vert}\right\vert\le\frac{\epsilon}{k}∣∣∣∣∣​∣N∣∣R(N,X,y)∣​−∣N∣∣R(N,X,y)∣​∣∣∣∣∣​≤kϵ​

已经对 1−δ1-\delta1−δ，O/Ω(1ϵlog⁡1δ)O/\Omega(\frac{1}{\epsilon}\log\frac{1}{\delta})O/Ω(ϵ1​logδ1​), Chernoff, Hoeffding 这样的东西 PTSD 了谢谢

NNN is a random sample of N\mathcal NN. Hoeffding’s inequality implies that for any fixed (X,y)(X,y)(X,y), a sample of size ∣N∣=O(1ϵ^2log⁡1δ^)|N|=O(\frac{1}{\hat\epsilon^2}\log\frac{1}{\hat\delta})∣N∣=O(ϵ^21​logδ^1​) is sufficient to achieve

∣∣R(N,X,y)∣∣N∣−∣R(N,X,y)∣∣N∣∣≤ϵ^\left\vert\frac{\vert R(N,X,y)\vert}{\vert N\vert}-\frac{\vert R(\mathcal N,X,y)\vert}{\vert\mathcal N\vert}\right\vert\le\hat\epsilon∣∣∣∣∣​∣N∣∣R(N,X,y)∣​−∣N∣∣R(N,X,y)∣​∣∣∣∣∣​≤ϵ^

with probability at least 1−δ^1-\hat\delta1−δ^. Note that there are q=m⋅Cmkq=m\cdot C_m^kq=m⋅Cmk​ possible choice of (X,y)(X,y)(X,y) over which we take the union bound. Setting δ=δ^q,ϵ=ϵ^k\delta=\frac{\hat\delta}{q},\epsilon=\frac{\hat\epsilon}{k}δ=qδ^​,ϵ=kϵ^​ is sufficient for the union bound to yield the theorem.

We say solution XXX is ρ\rhoρ-PROP to (1+ϵ)(1+\epsilon)(1+ϵ)-deviations if for all y∈My\in\mathcal My∈M and for all S⊆NS\subseteq\mathcal NS⊆N where ∣S∣≥(1+ϵ)nk|S|\ge(1+\epsilon)\frac{n}{k}∣S∣≥(1+ϵ)kn​, there exists some i∈Si\in Si∈S s.t. ρ⋅d(i,y)≥Di(X)\rho\cdot d(i,y)\ge D_i(X)ρ⋅d(i,y)≥Di​(X). Note that if XXX is ρ\rhoρ-PROP to 111-deviation, it is simply ρ\rhoρ-PROP.

🤔Corollary 1. Let N⊂NN\subset\mathcal NN⊂N be a uniform random sample of size ∣N∣=Ω(k3ϵ2ln⁡mδ)|N|=\Omega(\frac{k^3}{\epsilon^2}\ln\frac{m}{\delta})∣N∣=Ω(ϵ2k3​lnδm​). Suppose X⊆MX\subseteq MX⊆M with ∣X∣=k|X|=k∣X∣=k is ρ\rhoρ-PROP w.r.t. NNN. Then with probability at least 1−δ1-\delta1−δ, XXX is ρ\rhoρ-PROP to (1+ϵ)(1+\epsilon)(1+ϵ)-deviations w.r.t. N\mathcal NN.

Linear Time Implementation

We can approximately implement Greedy Capture in nearly linear time, comparable to the running time of the standard kkk-means heuristic.

🤔Corollary 2. Greedy Capture, when run on M\mathcal MM and a random sample N⊆NN\subseteq\mathcal NN⊆N of size ∣N∣=Θ~(k3ϵ2)|N|=\tilde\Theta(\frac{k^3}{\epsilon^2})∣N∣=Θ~(ϵ2k3​), provides a solution that is (1+2)(1+\sqrt 2)(1+2​)-PROP to (1+ϵ)(1+\epsilon)(1+ϵ)-deviation with high probability in O~(k3ϵ2m)\tilde O(\frac{k^3}{\epsilon^2}m)O~(ϵ2k3​m) time.

There are similar speedup for Local Capture algorithm.

Efficient Auditing

Audit Problem: To answer whether a solution produced happens to be proportional.

Given N,M\mathcal N,\mathcal MN,M, X⊂NX\subset \mathcal NX⊂N with ∣X∣<k|X|\lt k∣X∣<k, find the minimum value of ρ\rhoρ s.t. XXX is ρ\rhoρ-PROP.

Trivial idea: One can solve the audit problem exactly in O((k+m)n)O((k+m)n)O((k+m)n) time by computing for each y∈My\in\mathcal My∈M, the quantity ρy\rho_yρy​, the ⌈nk⌉\lceil\frac{n}{k}\rceil⌈kn​⌉ largest value of Di(X)d(i,y)\frac{D_i(X)}{d(i,y)}d(i,y)Di​(X)​. Then find the yyy that maximizes ρy\rho_yρy​. Again, this takes quadratic time, which can be worse than the time taken to find the clustering itself.

(ϵ,δ)(\epsilon,\delta)(ϵ,δ)-Audit Problem: Find the minimum value of ρ\rhoρ s.t. XXX is ρ\rhoρ-PROP to (1+ϵ)(1+\epsilon)(1+ϵ)-deviations with probability at least 1−δ1-\delta1−δ. This problem can be efficiently solved by using a random sample N⊆NN\subseteq\mathcal NN⊆N of points to conduct the audit.

🤔Corollary 3. The (ϵ,δ)(\epsilon,\delta)(ϵ,δ)-Audit Problem can be solved in O~((k+m)k3ϵ2)\tilde O((k+m)\frac{k^3}{\epsilon^2})O~((k+m)ϵ2k3​) time.

Implementation and Empirical Results

Highly depends on which dataset.

Conclusion and Open Problems

The exact PROP may not exist.

Efficient algorithms for computing approximate PROP solutions.

Constrained optimization and sampling for further applications.

Finally, PROP on real data: data dependent trade-off between PROP and kkk-means objective.

Open Problems

❓Can we close the approximate factor gap between 222 and 1+21+\sqrt21+2​?

❓Is there a more efficient and easily explainable algorithm for optimizing total cost subject to PROP?

❓Is there any other fair solution concepts for clustering?

❓Can the idea of PROP as a group fairness concept be adapted for supervised learning tasks like classification and regression?

Bonus: Trying to break the 1+21+\sqrt21+2​ barrier

Look at the example for 1+21+\sqrt 21+2​ lower bound by applying Greedy Capture.

Let’s look at the half.

a1a2a3
x11112−1\sqrt2-12​−11+21+\sqrt21+2​
x21+21+\sqrt21+2​1−ϵ1-\epsilon1−ϵ1−ϵ1-\epsilon1−ϵ

The reason why this is (1+2)(1+\sqrt2)(1+2​)-PROP is that x2x_2x2​ clinches a2,a3a_2,a_3a2​,a3​ prior to x1x_1x1​.

But if we choose x1x_1x1​ as clustering center, the clustering will become PROP!

Now consider some modification on Greedy Capture, making it better approximation for PROP.

Pseudo Code for “Advanced” Greedy Capture

Input: k,N,Mk,\mathcal N,\mathcal Mk,N,M.

Output: a set of XXX containing at most kkk cluster centers.

  1. Δj←0∀j∈M\Delta_j\gets0\forall j\in\mathcal MΔj​←0∀j∈M
  2. X←∅,N←N,C←∅X\gets\empty,N\gets\mathcal N,C\gets\emptyX←∅,N←N,C←∅
  3. While N≠∅N\neq\emptyN=∅ do
    1. Let i∈M,x∈N╲Ci\in\mathcal M,x\in N\diagdown Ci∈M,x∈N╲C s.t. d(i,x)−Δid(i,x)-\Delta_id(i,x)−Δi​ is minimum
    2. Δi←d(i,x)\Delta_i\gets d(i,x)Δi​←d(i,x)
    3. C←C∪{x}C\gets C\cup\{x\}C←C∪{x}
    4. If i∈Xi\in Xi∈X then
      • N←N╲{x}N\gets N\diagdown\{x\}N←N╲{x}
    5. else if i∈M╲Xi\in\mathcal M\diagdown Xi∈M╲X and ∣B(i,Δi)∩C∩N∣=⌈n/k⌉|B(i,\Delta_i)\cap C\cap N|=\lceil n/k\rceil∣B(i,Δi​)∩C∩N∣=⌈n/k⌉ then
      • X←X∪{x}X\gets X\cup\{x\}X←X∪{x}
      • N←N╲(B(i,Δi)∩C)N\gets N\diagdown (B(i,\Delta_i)\cap C)N←N╲(B(i,Δi​)∩C)
  4. return XXX

On the (1+2)(1+\sqrt 2)(1+2​)-PROP example, this “Advanced” Greedy Capture computes a exactly PROP clustering.

On the 222-PROP example, this algorithm computes 222-PROP clustering.

Now we haven’t prove the correctness of this algorithm.

Does this algorithm guarantees the lower bound of 222?

entry.title: 算法和计算复杂度 9 Circuit Lower Bounds
entry.content:
Parity function is not in AC0AC^0AC0.

MAJ∉AC0MAJ\not\in AC^0MAJ∈AC0.

NEXP⊈ACC0NEXP\not\subseteq ACC^0NEXP⊆ACC0.

Some unknown proposition:

  • whether NP⊆ACC0NP\subseteq ACC^0NP⊆ACC0.

  • whether EXP⊆ACC0EXP\subseteq ACC^0EXP⊆ACC0.

  • whether NEXP⊆TC0NEXP\subseteq TC^0NEXP⊆TC0.

  • whether all languages in NEXPNEXPNEXP can be computed by depth 222 circuits consisting of weighted linear threshold gates.

The Razborov-Smolensky Lower Bound

The lower bounds for class AC0[pr]AC^0[p^r]AC0[pr], where ppp is a prime.

Main idea: convert Boolean circuit of small size into a low-degree probabilistic polynomial.

Here we consider r=1r=1r=1.

📖Definition 43. Let F\mathbb FF be a field. By a probabilistic polynomial PPP in nnn variables of total degree ddd over F\mathbb FF we mean a random variable assuming as value such polynomials. Let f:{0,1}n→{0,1}f:\{0,1\}^n\to\{0,1\}f:{0,1}n→{0,1} be a Boolean function. We say that PPP computes fff with error ϵ\epsilonϵ if Pr⁡[P(x)=f(x)]≥1−ϵ\Pr[P(x)=f(x)]\ge1-\epsilonPr[P(x)=f(x)]≥1−ϵ for all x∈{0,1}nx\in\{0,1\}^nx∈{0,1}n. Similarly we say that PPP computes fff with one-sided error ϵ\epsilonϵ if PPP computes fff with error ϵ\epsilonϵ and furthermore we have Pr⁡[P(x)=f(x)]=1\Pr[P(x)=f(x)]=1Pr[P(x)=f(x)]=1 for all x∈{0,1}nx\in\{0,1\}^nx∈{0,1}n where f(x)=0f(x)=0f(x)=0.

Then construct a probabilistic polynomial form an AC0[p]AC^0[p]AC0[p] circuit.

🤔Lemma 13. Let ppp be a prime and let CCC be a depth hhh circuit with at most SSS unbounded fanin AND,OR,MODpAND,OR,MOD_pAND,OR,MODp​ as well as negation gates computing a Boolean function fff. Let t≥1t\ge1t≥1 be an arbitrary integer. Then for any nnn there exist a probabilistic polynomial in nnn variables of total degree at most (pt)h(pt)^h(pt)h over Zp\mathbb Z_pZp​ computing fff with error Spt\frac{S}{p^t}ptS​.

Probabilistic polynomial for each of the gates of CCC. Each of these will be of degree at most ptptpt and compute the gate function with error 1pt\frac{1}{p^t}pt1​.

Composing these will give probabilistic polynomial of degree at most (pt)h(pt)^h(pt)h computing fff and with error at most Spt\frac{S}{p^t}ptS​ by a union bound.

Input gates: xix_ixi​ can be computed by the polynomials xix_ixi​ with error 000. xˉi\bar x_ixˉi​ can be computed by the polynomials 1−xi1-x_i1−xi​ with error 000.

Negation gates: ¬z\neg z¬z can be computed by the polynomial 1−y1-y1−y with error 000.

MODpMOD_pMODp​ gate with inputs z1,⋯ ,zkz_1,\cdots,z_kz1​,⋯,zk​ can be computed by the polynomial

(∑i=1kzi)p−1\left(\sum_{i=1}^kz_i\right)^{p-1}(i=1∑k​zi​)p−1

with error 000 by Fermat’s little theorem.

OROROR gate with inputs z1,⋯ ,zkz_1,\cdots,z_kz1​,⋯,zk​: Consider picking a1,⋯ ,ak∈Zpa_1,\cdots,a_k\in\mathbb Z_pa1​,⋯,ak​∈Zp​ uniformly and independently at random. Using Fermat’s little theorem again, we have the polynomial

(∑i=1kaizi)p−1\left(\sum_{i=1}^ka_iz_i\right)^{p-1}(i=1∑k​ai​zi​)p−1

computes OR(z1,⋯ ,zk)OR(z_1,\cdots,z_k)OR(z1​,⋯,zk​) with one-sided error 1p\frac{1}{p}p1​. In order to decrease the error, use success amplification using ttt independent trials.

1−∏j=1t(1−(∑i=1kaijzi)p−1),1-\prod_{j=1}^t\left(1-\left(\sum_{i=1}^ka_{ij}z_i\right)^{p-1}\right),1−j=1∏t​⎝⎛​1−(i=1∑k​aij​zi​)p−1⎠⎞​,

which then computes OR(z1,⋯ ,zk)OR(z_1,\cdots,z_k)OR(z1​,⋯,zk​) with one-sided error 1pt\frac{1}{p^t}pt1​.

Analogously, for ANDANDAND gate, the probabilistic polynomial

1−∏j=1t(1−(∑i=1kaij(1−zi))p−1).1-\prod_{j=1}^t\left(1-\left(\sum_{i=1}^ka_{ij}(1-z_i)\right)^{p-1}\right).1−j=1∏t​⎝⎛​1−(i=1∑k​aij​(1−zi​))p−1⎠⎞​.

🤔Lemma 14. Let PPP be a probabilistic polynomial of degree ddd and let f:{a,b}n→Ff:\{a,b\}^n\to\mathbb Ff:{a,b}n→F be a function s.t. Pr⁡[P(x)=f(x)]≥1−ϵ\Pr[P(x)=f(x)]\ge1-\epsilonPr[P(x)=f(x)]≥1−ϵ. Then there exists a polynomial P′P'P′ of degree ddd and a set G⊆{a,b}nG\subseteq\{a,b\}^nG⊆{a,b}n with ∣G∣≥(1−ϵ)2n|G|\ge(1-\epsilon)2^n∣G∣≥(1−ϵ)2n s.t. P(x)=f(x)P(x)=f(x)P(x)=f(x) for all x∈Gx\in Gx∈G.

Linearity of expectation:

E[∣x∈{a,b}n:P(x)=f(x)∣]=∑x∈{a,b}nPr⁡[P(x)=f(x)]≥2n(1−ϵ),\mathbb E[|x\in\{a,b\}^n:P(x)=f(x)|]=\sum_{x\in\{a,b\}^n}\Pr[P(x)=f(x)]\ge2^n(1-\epsilon),E[∣x∈{a,b}n:P(x)=f(x)∣]=x∈{a,b}n∑​Pr[P(x)=f(x)]≥2n(1−ϵ),

A low-degree polynomial is equal to the product of all variables on a set G⊆{a,b}nG\subseteq\{a,b\}^nG⊆{a,b}n enables one to replace all polynomials by equivalent polynomials on the set GGG of degree significantly smaller than nnn.

🤔Lemma 15. Let PPP be a polynomial in nnn variables of total degree Δ\DeltaΔ over a field F\mathbb FF. Let a,b∈Fa,b\in\mathbb Fa,b∈F and suppose G⊆{a,b}nG\subseteq\{a,b\}^nG⊆{a,b}n is s.t.

∀y∈G:P(y)=∏i=1nyi.\forall y\in G:P(y)=\prod_{i=1}^ny_i.∀y∈G:P(y)=i=1∏n​yi​.

Then for every function f:G→Ff:G\to\mathbb Ff:G→F there exists a polynomial PfP_fPf​ of total degree at most n+Δ2\frac{n+\Delta}{2}2n+Δ​ s.t.

∀y∈G:Pf(y)=f(y).\forall y\in G:P_f(y)=f(y).∀y∈G:Pf​(y)=f(y).

Let f:G→Ff:G\to\mathbb Ff:G→F be any function. Define multilinear polynomial QfQ_fQf​:

Qf(y)=∑x∈G(f(x)(∏i:xi=ab−yib−a)(∏i:xi=ba−yia−b)).Q_f(y)=\sum_{x\in G}\left(f(x)\left(\prod_{i:x_i=a}\frac{b-y_i}{b-a}\right)\left(\prod_{i:x_i=b}\frac{a-y_i}{a-b}\right)\right).Qf​(y)=x∈G∑​(f(x)(i:xi​=a∏​b−ab−yi​​)(i:xi​=b∏​a−ba−yi​​)).

Clearly, Qf(y)=f(y)∀y∈GQ_f(y)=f(y)\forall y\in GQf​(y)=f(y)∀y∈G. Using PPP, any monomial of degree ddd can be replaced by an equivalent polynomial of degree n−d+Δn-d+\Deltan−d+Δ since

∏i∈Iyi=(∏i=1nyi)(∏i∉I1yi)=P(y)∏i∉I(1ab−yib−a+1ba−yia−b).\prod_{i\in I}y_i=\left(\prod_{i=1}^ny_i\right)\left(\prod_{i\not\in I}\frac{1}{y_i}\right)=P(y)\prod_{i\not\in I}\left(\frac{1}{a}\frac{b-y_i}{b-a}+\frac{1}{b}\frac{a-y_i}{a-b}\right).i∈I∏​yi​=(i=1∏n​yi​)⎝⎛​i∈I∏​yi​1​⎠⎞​=P(y)i∈I∏​(a1​b−ab−yi​​+b1​a−ba−yi​​).

Thus we replace each monomial of QfQ_fQf​ of degree d>n+Δ2d\gt\frac{n+\Delta}{2}d>2n+Δ​ by an equivalent polynomial of degree n−d+Δ<n+Δ2n-d+\Delta\lt\frac{n+\Delta}{2}n−d+Δ<2n+Δ​. We can thus take PfP_fPf​ to be the sum of these together with the monomials of QfQ_fQf​ degree at most n+Δ2\frac{n+\Delta}{2}2n+Δ​.

One may convert any polynomial into a multi-linear polynomial of the same degree which is equivalent on a given hypercube {a,b}n\{a,b\}^n{a,b}n.

🤔Lemma 16. Let a,b∈Fa,b\in\mathbb Fa,b∈F and let PPP be a polynomial of degree ddd. Then there exists a multi-linear polynomial P′P'P′ of degree at most ddd s.t. P(x)=P′(x)P(x)=P'(x)P(x)=P′(x) for all x∈{a,b}nx\in\{a,b\}^nx∈{a,b}n.

An occurrence of xikx_i^kxik​ in PPP may be replaced by the polynomial

xi−ba−bak+xi−ab−abk,\frac{x_i-b}{a-b}a^k+\frac{x_i-a}{b-a}b^k,a−bxi​−b​ak+b−axi​−a​bk,

which can never increase the degree.

🤔Lemma 17. For all integers n≥1n\ge 1n≥1:

4nπ(n+1)≤C2nn≤4nπn\frac{4^n}{\sqrt{\pi(n+1)}}\le C_{2n}^n\le\frac{4^n}{\sqrt{\pi n}}π(n+1)​4n​≤C2nn​≤πn​4n​

🤔Corollary 10. For all integers n≥1n\ge1n≥1:

C⌈n/2⌉n≤2nπ⌈n/2⌉.C_{\lceil n/2\rceil}^n\le\frac{2^n}{\sqrt{\pi\lceil n/2\rceil}}.C⌈n/2⌉n​≤π⌈n/2⌉​2n​.

🤔Proposition 13. Let PPP be a polynomial in nnn variables of total degree Δ\DeltaΔ over a field F\mathbb FF. Let a,b∈Fa,b\in\mathbb Fa,b∈F and suppose G⊆{a,b}nG\subseteq \{a,b\}^nG⊆{a,b}n is s.t.

y∈G:P(y)=∏i=1nyi.y\in G:P(y)=\prod_{i=1}^ny_i.y∈G:P(y)=i=1∏n​yi​.

Then

∣G∣≤2n(12+410Δn).|G|\le 2^n\left(\frac{1}{2}+\frac{4}{10}\frac{\Delta}{\sqrt n}\right).∣G∣≤2n(21​+104​n​Δ​).

By Lemma 16, assume that PPP is multilinear.

The number of functions f:G→Ff:G\to\mathbb Ff:G→F, which amounts to p∣G∣p^{|G|}p∣G∣, must be less than the number of multilinear polynomials of degree at most n+Δ2\frac{n+\Delta}{2}2n+Δ​, which amounts to pMp^MpM, where MMM denotes the number of monomials on nnn variables of degree at most n+Δ2\frac{n+\Delta}{2}2n+Δ​. It follows that ∣G∣≤M|G|\le M∣G∣≤M.

Then conclude by estimating MMM.

M=∑i=0⌊n+Δ2⌋Cni=2n−1+∑i=⌈n/2⌉⌊n+Δ2⌋Cni≤2n−1+Δ22nπn/2≤2n−1+410Δ2nn,M=\sum_{i=0}^{\lfloor\frac{n+\Delta}{2}\rfloor}C_n^i=2^{n-1}+\sum_{i=\lceil n/2\rceil}^{\lfloor\frac{n+\Delta}{2}\rfloor}C_n^i\le2^{n-1}+\frac{\Delta}{2}\frac{2^n}{\sqrt{\pi n/2}}\le 2^{n-1}+\frac{4}{10}\frac{\Delta2^n}{\sqrt n},M=i=0∑⌊2n+Δ​⌋​Cni​=2n−1+i=⌈n/2⌉∑⌊2n+Δ​⌋​Cni​≤2n−1+2Δ​πn/2​2n​≤2n−1+104​n​Δ2n​,

where CniC_n^iCni​ is estimated by central binomial coefficient, for i>n/2i\gt n/2i>n/2, and use 2π≥104\sqrt{2\pi}\ge\frac{10}{4}2π​≥410​,

Finally combine the construction of the probabilistic polynomials with the counting argument to derive a circuit lower bound.

🎯Theorem 46 . Let p≠2p\neq 2p=2 be a prime. Suppose that CCC is depth hhh circuit with at most SSS unbounded fanin AND,OR,MODpAND,OR,MOD_pAND,OR,MODp​ as well as NEGNEGNEG gates computing MOD2MOD_2MOD2​. Then

S=2Ω(n12h).S=2^{\Omega(n^{\frac{1}{2h}})}.S=2Ω(n2h1​).

Lemma 13, Lemma 14, Proposition 13.

🎯Theorem 47 (Smolensky). Let ppp be a prime. Suppose that CCC is a depth hhh circuit with at most SSS unbounded fanin AND,OR,MODprAND,OR,MOD_{p^r}AND,OR,MODpr​ gates for a constant r≥1r\ge1r≥1 as well as NEGNEGNEG gates computing function MODqMOD_qMODq​, where q≠pq\neq pq=p is a prime. Then

S=2Ω(n12h).S=2^{\Omega(n^{\frac{1}{2h}})}.S=2Ω(n2h1​).

这个电路下界真的是人想的出来的吗！！！

entry.title: 丹麦语 DU 3.3 6 Foreninger og klubber
entry.content:
spild af penge 浪费钱

terning -en, -er, -erne 骰子

  • slå med terningen 掷骰子

Det er din/min tur. 轮到你/我了

brik -ken, -ker, -kerne 棋子，标志，令牌，“token”

træls 悲惨的

辨析 om/i + 一段时间

  • om tre uger 在三周内
  • i tre uger 三周（一段时间）

逻辑连接词

både … og …

可以连接大于等于两个主体，表示“都”的意思。

Eks.

  • Søren har både køer, grise og heste. 索亨有牛、猪和马。
  • Søren både sover og spiser i sengen.
  • Søren hører altid musik, både når han er hjemme, og når han er på arbejde.

hverken … eller …

表示“既不……也不……”，可以连接大于等于两个主体。

Eks.

  • Søren har hverken køer, grise eller heste.
  • Søren hverken sover eller spiser i sengen.
  • Søren hører altid musik, hverken når han er hjemme, eller når han er på arbejde.

begge/begge to

表示“两者都”，指代比较具体的人或事。

begge 只能放在名词之前，begge to 放在名词之后

  • Begge børnene er meget trætte.
  • Børnene er begge (to) meget trætte.

begge dele

表示“两者都”，指代抽象、概括性的事情

  • Vil du have rødvin eller hvidvin? - Det er lige meget. Jeg drikker begge dele.
  • Hvad kan du bedst lide: actionfilm eller komedier? - Jeg kan lide begge dele.

Modalverber 补充

  • tør 敢于

  • bør 应该

  • behøver 需要（一般用在否定句、疑问句中）

Fritidstilbud, foreninger og klubber

forening -en, -er, -erne 工会，协会，团体

arrangement -et, -er, -erne 活动，事件，程序 （法语的发音）

frivillig -t, -e 自愿的

at være med til 参与

at være medlem af 成为其中一员

at ses med nogen 去见某人

at være en del af 成为……的一部分

at orientere sig om 了解某事

entry.title: Efficient ReliK 3 Parallel For Loop
entry.content:
This week, I am mainly working on parallelization of enumerating xh′r′t′x_{h'r't'}xh′r′t′​: for u,v in nx.DiGraph(M).subgraph(subgraph).edges().

Target Code

😭First Try: ThreadPoolExecutor

On Countries, for each subgraph it takes around 3000 ms, while on SmallcodeX, it takes around 120 s per subgraph.

Result😩

This approach is definitely negative optimization.

❌ABORTED.

😭Second Try: Parallelization on GPU

Then try to do parallelization using PyTorch + CUDA.

Result😢

However, it seems that there is no speed up in the experiment, for some different num_parallel values. I suspect that it is executed sequentially. Maybe I have not thoroughly understood the code.

😃Third Try: multiprocessing

Idea is straight forward.

I have num_processors processors. Then I partition the edges list(nx.DiGraph(M).subgraph(subgraph).edges()) into num_processors parts.

Each processor is responsible for a corresponding part.

I need to write the method process_edges_partition outside to process each part.

Experiment🤩

I ran experiment on dataset Countries and CodexSmall respectively.

We want to speed up the process for calculating ReliK scores.

Setting

Set num_processors = 10;

Using TransE embeddings.

Dataset - Countries

python experiment_controller.py -d Countries -e TransE -t ReliK

For raw implementation, it takes around 470 seconds.

For multiprocessing optimization, it takes around 123 seconds.

Speedup: Around 3.8x

Dataset - CodexSmall

python experiment_controller.py -d CodexSmall -e TransE -t ReliK

For raw implementation, it takes around 12900 seconds = 215 minutes ≈ 3.58 hours.

For multiprocessing optimization, it takes around 1610 second ≈26.8 minutes❗👍

Speedup: Around 8.0x

Staying up debugging until 2:30 a.m. finally paid off.😎

entry.title: 丹麦语 DU 3.3 5 At beskrive
entry.content:
Ordforråd om højskoler

sabbatår -et, -, -ene gap 年

valgfri -t, - eller -e 可选的

  • valgfri fag 选修科目

tilbyde -r, tilbød, tilbudt 提供

vælge -r, valgte, valgt 选择

  • Du skal selv vælge din fag på højskolen.

at kunne tænke sig = at have lyst til 有兴趣做某事，想做某事

  • Jeg kunne tænke mig, at gå på en kreativ højskole.

Infinitivkæder

Hun vil begynde at lære at køre bil.

  • ‘at lære’ er objekt for ‘begynde’
  • ‘at køre bil’ er objekt for ‘at lære’

Han har lovet at prøve at holde op med at ryge.

  • ‘at prøve’ er objekt for ‘lovet’
  • ‘at holde op med’ er objekt for ‘at prøve’
  • ‘at ryge’ er objekt for ‘at holde op med’

Sætningskløvning med DET

  1. Fremhævet subjekt: Det er/var … , der … (V) …

    Eks.: De rige gik på latinskoler og universiteter.

    Svar: Det var de rige, der gik på latinskoler og universiteter.

  2. Fremhævet objekt: Det er/var … , S - V

    Eks.: Almindelige mennesker fik praktiske kundskaber på folkehøjskolerne.

    Svar: Det var praktiske kundskaber, almindelige mennesker fik på folkehøjskolerne.

  3. Fremhævet adverbial: Det er/var … , S - V

    Eks.: Almindelige mennesker fik praktiske kundskaber på folkehøjskolerne.

    Svar: Det var på folkehøjskolerne, almindelige mennesker fik praktiske kundskaber.

entry.title: Fair AI/ML 1 Core-Stability Federated Learning
entry.content:
I will begin a new project work 24 Fall: FAIRNESS IN AI/ML THROUGH THE LENS OF SOCIAL CHOICE

The basic outline is following Tutorial: Fairness in AI/ML via Social Choice by Evi Micha & Nisarg Shah in EC 2024.

The first paper I have read in last semester, Fairness in Federated Learning via Core-Stability, which was one of the possible topics.

Brief notes is here.

I will try to understand some mathematical proof in this semester.

Core-Stability

Revisit the definition of Core-Stability: A predictor θ∈P\theta\in Pθ∈P is called core stable if there exist no other θ′∈P\theta'\in Pθ′∈P and no subset SSS of agents, s.t. ∣S∣nui(θ′)≥ui(θ)\frac{|S|}{n}u_i(\theta')\ge u_i(\theta)n∣S∣​ui​(θ′)≥ui​(θ) for all i∈Si\in Si∈S, with at least one strict inequality.

⚠️⚠️⚠️What is WRONG with the claim

Setting S=[n]S=[n]S=[n] in definition, there is no predictor θ′∈P\theta'\in Pθ′∈P where ∑i∈[n]ui(θ′)ui(θ)>n\sum_{i\in[n]}\frac{u_i(\theta')}{u_i(\theta)}\gt n∑i∈[n]​ui​(θ)ui​(θ′)​>n.

According to the definition, when we plug in S=[n]S=[n]S=[n], there exist no θ′∈P\theta'\in Pθ′∈P s.t.

ui(θ′)≥ui(θ)∀i∈S⇔ui(θ′)ui(θ)≥1∀i∈Su_i(\theta')\ge u_i(\theta)\forall i\in S\\\Lrarr\frac{u_i(\theta')}{u_i(\theta)}\ge 1\forall i\in Sui​(θ′)≥ui​(θ)∀i∈S⇔ui​(θ)ui​(θ′)​≥1∀i∈S

with at least one strict inequality.

The problem is, can we directly sum it up, then we have ∑iui(θ′)ui(θ)>n\sum_i\frac{u_i(\theta')}{u_i(\theta)}\gt n∑i​ui​(θ)ui​(θ′)​>n???

There is a counterexample:

  • n=2n=2n=2, θ\thetaθ is core-stable, we only have two feasible predictors θ,θ′:θ′≠θ\theta,\theta':\theta'\neq\thetaθ,θ′:θ′=θ, ϵ→0+\epsilon\to0^+ϵ→0+.

    agent 111agent 222
    θ\thetaθ111111
    θ′\theta'θ′2−ϵ2-\epsilon2−ϵ1−ϵ1-\epsilon1−ϵ

  • Verifying the core-stability of θ\thetaθ:

    • For S={1}S=\{1\}S={1}, we have ∣S∣nui(θ′)=12u1(θ′)=1−ϵ2<1=u1(θ)\frac{|S|}{n}u_i(\theta')=\frac{1}{2}u_1(\theta')=1-\frac{\epsilon}{2}\lt1=u_1(\theta)n∣S∣​ui​(θ′)=21​u1​(θ′)=1−2ϵ​<1=u1​(θ). Which satisfy the condition.
    • For S={2}S=\{2\}S={2}, we have 12u2(θ′)=1−ϵ2<1=u2(θ)\frac{1}{2}u_2(\theta')=\frac{1-\epsilon}{2}\lt1=u_2(\theta)21​u2​(θ′)=21−ϵ​<1=u2​(θ). Which satisfy the condition.
    • For S={1,2}S=\{1,2\}S={1,2}, we have u1(θ′)=2−ϵ>1=u1(θ)u_1(\theta')=2-\epsilon\gt1=u_1(\theta)u1​(θ′)=2−ϵ>1=u1​(θ) and u2(θ′)=1−ϵ<1=u2(θ)u_2(\theta')=1-\epsilon\lt1=u_2(\theta)u2​(θ′)=1−ϵ<1=u2​(θ). Which also satisfy the condition that some scaled utility is less than the original utility.

    But ∑iui(θ′)ui(θ)=u1(θ′)u1(θ)+u2(θ′)u2(θ)=3−2ϵ>2\sum_i\frac{u_i(\theta')}{u_i(\theta)}=\frac{u_1(\theta')}{u_1(\theta)}+\frac{u_2(\theta')}{u_2(\theta)}=3-2\epsilon\gt2∑i​ui​(θ)ui​(θ′)​=u1​(θ)u1​(θ′)​+u2​(θ)u2​(θ′)​=3−2ϵ>2!

Scaled factor ∣S∣/n|S|/n∣S∣/n suggests some kind of proportionality here. Basically core-stability means there is no big benefit for agent to form a coalition.

Core means “no deviating subgroup”

Core stability is very strong, only exists in special cases.

Advantage

More fair than FedAvg. MMM is a very large integer.

Agent 1Agent 2Agent 3
θ1\theta_1θ1​aaaaaaM⋅aM\cdot aM⋅a
θ2\theta_2θ2​10a10a10a10a10a10a0.9M⋅a0.9M\cdot a0.9M⋅a

In FedAvg, θ2\theta_2θ2​ is preferred, but not fair to Agent 1 and 2. (They have incentive to collide.)

Robustness to poor local data quality of agents.

❗Scaling the utility of any single agents does not change the core-stable allocation.

❗Some Ideas around Sum-of-ratio Property

Is there scenario s.t. none of predictors is core-stable?

Yes. The example

agent 111agent 222
θ\thetaθ1112+ϵ2+\epsilon2+ϵ
θ′\theta'θ′2+ϵ2+\epsilon2+ϵ111

shows that none of θ,θ′\theta,\theta'θ,θ′ is core-stable.

Some New Definitions

Ideas from Iannis. I was amazed by his ability to invent some new notions 😮

📖Definition of pessimistic price of core-stability:

PoCSpessimistic=max⁡θ is core-stablemax⁡θ′∈P∑i∈[n]ui(θ′)ui(θ)PoCS_{pessimistic}=\max_{\theta\text{ is core-stable}}\max_{\theta'\in P}\sum_{i\in[n]}\frac{u_i(\theta')}{u_i(\theta)}PoCSpessimistic​=θ is core-stablemax​θ′∈Pmax​i∈[n]∑​ui​(θ)ui​(θ′)​

📖Definition of optimistic price of core-stability:

PoCSoptimistic=min⁡θ is core-stablemax⁡θ′∈P∑i∈[n]ui(θ′)ui(θ)PoCS_{optimistic}=\min_{\theta\text{ is core-stable}}\max_{\theta'\in P}\sum_{i\in[n]}\frac{u_i(\theta')}{u_i(\theta)}PoCSoptimistic​=θ is core-stablemin​θ′∈Pmax​i∈[n]∑​ui​(θ)ui​(θ′)​

Conjecture about Price of Core-Stability (Has been disproved)

If the set of core-stable predictors is non-empty, does one predictor in the set be the optimistic price of core-stability?

We want to proof/disproof this conjectures.

Let’s consider the scenario with two agents.

agents\predictorsθ\thetaθ…θ′′\theta''θ′′…
11…?…
21…?…

Assume that θ\thetaθ is core-stable. The question is, does there exist predictor θ′′\theta''θ′′ that minimizing max⁡θ′∈P∑i∈[n]ui(θ′)ui(θ′′)\max_{\theta'\in P}\sum_{i\in[n]}\frac{u_i(\theta')}{u_i(\theta'')}maxθ′∈P​∑i∈[n]​ui​(θ′′)ui​(θ′)​ and not core-stable? If the answer is true, then we disproof the conjecture.

Disprove it

Consider the scenario with 2 agents and 3 feasible predictors:

agents\predictorsθ1\theta_1θ1​θ2\theta_2θ2​θ3\theta_3θ3​
11111−ϵ1-\epsilon1−ϵ222
21112221−ϵ1-\epsilon1−ϵ

By symmetry, θ2\theta_2θ2​ and θ3\theta_3θ3​ are equivalent.

Check whether θ1\theta_1θ1​ is core-stable

  • Consider S={1}S=\{1\}S={1}:

    12u1(θ2)=1−ϵ2<1=u1(θ1)=112u1(θ3)=22=1≤1=u1(θ1)=1\frac{1}{2}u_1(\theta_2)=\frac{1-\epsilon}{2}\lt 1=u_1(\theta_1)=1\\\frac{1}{2}u_1(\theta_3)=\frac{2}{2}=1\le 1=u_1(\theta_1)=121​u1​(θ2​)=21−ϵ​<1=u1​(θ1​)=121​u1​(θ3​)=22​=1≤1=u1​(θ1​)=1

  • Consider S={2}S=\{2\}S={2}:

    12u2(θ3)=1−ϵ2<1=u2(θ1)=112u2(θ2)=22=1≤1=u2(θ1)=1\frac{1}{2}u_2(\theta_3)=\frac{1-\epsilon}{2}\lt 1=u_2(\theta_1)=1\\\frac{1}{2}u_2(\theta_2)=\frac{2}{2}=1\le 1=u_2(\theta_1)=121​u2​(θ3​)=21−ϵ​<1=u2​(θ1​)=121​u2​(θ2​)=22​=1≤1=u2​(θ1​)=1

  • Consider S={1,2}S=\{1,2\}S={1,2}:

    22u1(θ2)=1−ϵ<u1(θ1)=1,22u2(θ2)=2>u2(θ1)=122u1(θ3)=2>u1(θ1)=1,22u1(θ3)=1−ϵ<u1(θ1)=1\frac{2}{2}u_1(\theta_2)=1-\epsilon\lt u_1(\theta_1)=1,\frac{2}{2}u_2(\theta_2)=2\gt u_2(\theta_1)=1\\\frac{2}{2}u_1(\theta_3)=2\gt u_1(\theta_1)=1,\frac{2}{2}u_1(\theta_3)=1-\epsilon\lt u_1(\theta_1)=122​u1​(θ2​)=1−ϵ<u1​(θ1​)=1,22​u2​(θ2​)=2>u2​(θ1​)=122​u1​(θ3​)=2>u1​(θ1​)=1,22​u1​(θ3​)=1−ϵ<u1​(θ1​)=1

There is no subset satisfying all scaled value is greater or equal to original value. Thus, θ1\theta_1θ1​ is core-stable.

Check whether θ2,θ3\theta_2,\theta_3θ2​,θ3​ are core-stable

It suffices to check only θ2\theta_2θ2​.

  • Consider S={1}S=\{1\}S={1}:

    12u1(θ1)=12<u1(θ2)=1−ϵ12u1(θ3)=1>u1(θ2)=1−ϵ\frac{1}{2}u_1(\theta_1)=\frac{1}{2}\lt u_1(\theta_2)=1-\epsilon\\\frac{1}{2}u_1(\theta_3)=1\gt u_1(\theta_2)=1-\epsilon21​u1​(θ1​)=21​<u1​(θ2​)=1−ϵ21​u1​(θ3​)=1>u1​(θ2​)=1−ϵ

    Here scaled utility of θ3\theta_3θ3​ is strictly better than that of θ2\theta_2θ2​.

Thus θ2,θ3\theta_2,\theta_3θ2​,θ3​ are not core-stable.

Check the Sum of Ratio

For θ1\theta_1θ1​:

∑i∈{1,2}ui(θ2)ui(θ1)=3−ϵ∑i∈{1,2}ui(θ3)ui(θ1)=3−ϵ∴max⁡θ′≠θ1∑i∈{1,2}ui(θ′)ui(θ1)≈3\sum_{i\in\{1,2\}}\frac{u_i(\theta_2)}{u_i(\theta_1)}=3-\epsilon\\\sum_{i\in\{1,2\}}\frac{u_i(\theta_3)}{u_i(\theta_1)}=3-\epsilon\\\therefore\max_{\theta'\neq\theta_1}\sum_{i\in\{1,2\}}\frac{u_i(\theta')}{u_i(\theta_1)}\approx3i∈{1,2}∑​ui​(θ1​)ui​(θ2​)​=3−ϵi∈{1,2}∑​ui​(θ1​)ui​(θ3​)​=3−ϵ∴θ′=θ1​max​i∈{1,2}∑​ui​(θ1​)ui​(θ′)​≈3

For θ2\theta_2θ2​:

∑i∈{1,2}ui(θ1)ui(θ2)=12+11−ϵ≈32∑i∈{1,2}ui(θ3)ui(θ2)=21−ϵ+1−ϵ2≈52∴max⁡θ′≠θ2∑i∈{1,2}ui(θ′)ui(θ2)≈52\sum_{i\in\{1,2\}}\frac{u_i(\theta_1)}{u_i(\theta_2)}=\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{1-\epsilon}\approx\frac{3}{2}\\\sum_{i\in\{1,2\}}\frac{u_i(\theta_3)}{u_i(\theta_2)}=\frac{2}{1-\epsilon}+\frac{1-\epsilon}{2}\approx\frac{5}{2}\\\therefore\max_{\theta'\neq\theta_2}\sum_{i\in\{1,2\}}\frac{u_i(\theta')}{u_i(\theta_2)}\approx\frac{5}{2}i∈{1,2}∑​ui​(θ2​)ui​(θ1​)​=21​+1−ϵ1​≈23​i∈{1,2}∑​ui​(θ2​)ui​(θ3​)​=1−ϵ2​+21−ϵ​≈25​∴θ′=θ2​max​i∈{1,2}∑​ui​(θ2​)ui​(θ′)​≈25​

By symmetry, max⁡θ′≠θ3∑i∈{1,2}ui(θ′)ui(θ3)≈52\max_{\theta'\neq\theta_3}\sum_{i\in\{1,2\}}\frac{u_i(\theta')}{u_i(\theta_3)}\approx\frac{5}{2}maxθ′=θ3​​∑i∈{1,2}​ui​(θ3​)ui​(θ′)​≈25​.

The max of sum is not minimized by the only core-stable predictor.

Core-Stability in FL

CoreFed exists in Linear Regression and Logistic Regression (Classification)

Approximate core stable predictor exists in Deep Neural Network.

Existence

🤔Core-Stability exist in FL if:

  1. Utility function is continuous.

  2. The conical combination of utility functions is convex.

    ∀⟨α1,⋯ ,αn⟩∈R≥0n\forall\langle\alpha_1,\cdots,\alpha_n\rangle\in\mathbb R_{\ge0}^n∀⟨α1​,⋯,αn​⟩∈R≥0n​, the set C={θ∣∑i∈[n]αiui(θ)}C=\{\theta|\sum_{i\in[n]}\alpha_iu_i(\theta)\}C={θ∣∑i∈[n]​αi​ui​(θ)} is convex.

🤔Important theorem: Kakutani’s Fixed Point Theorem: A set valued function ϕ:D→2D\phi:D\to2^Dϕ:D→2D admits a fixed point, i.e. ∃d∈D\exist d\in D∃d∈D, s.t. d∈ϕ(d)d\in\phi(d)d∈ϕ(d), if

  1. DDD is non-empty, compact, and convex

Compact: The set is closed (It must contains all its boundary points), and bounded (It can be covered by a “sphere” with certain radius)

Convex: A set is convex if, for any two points xxx and yyy in the set, the line segment connecting xxx and yyy also lies entirely within the set. Mathematically, for any x,y∈Sx,y\in Sx,y∈S and any t∈[0,1]t \in [0, 1]t∈[0,1], the point: tx+(1−t)y∈Stx+(1−t)y\in Stx+(1−t)y∈S.

  1. ∀d∈D,ϕ(d)\forall d\in D,\phi(d)∀d∈D,ϕ(d) is non-empty, compact, and convex.
  2. ϕ(⋅)\phi(\cdot)ϕ(⋅) has a closed graph. i.e., ∀\forall∀ sequence (di)i∈N(d_i)_{i\in\mathbb N}(di​)i∈N​ converging to d∗d^*d∗ and (ei)i∈N(e_i)_{i\in\mathbb N}(ei​)i∈N​ converging to e∗e^*e∗, s.t. di∈Dd_i\in Ddi​∈D and ei∈ϕ(di)e_i\in\phi(d_i)ei​∈ϕ(di​), we have e∗∈ϕ(d∗)e^*\in\phi(d^*)e∗∈ϕ(d∗).

Define Core-Stable Feasible Predictors

∀θ∈P\forall\theta\in P∀θ∈P, ϕ(θ)={arg⁡max⁡d∈P∑i∈[n]ui(d)ui(θ)}\phi(\theta)=\{\arg\max_{d\in P}\sum_{i\in[n]}\frac{u_i(d)}{u_i(\theta)}\}ϕ(θ)={argmaxd∈P​∑i∈[n]​ui​(θ)ui​(d)​}.

Lemma 4.1: Let θ∈P\theta\in Pθ∈P be s.t. θ∈ϕ(θ)\theta\in\phi(\theta)θ∈ϕ(θ) (It is a fixed point). Then θ\thetaθ is a core-stable predictor.

Proof by contradiction.

By Takutani’s Theorem, it suffices to show that ϕ(⋅)\phi(\cdot)ϕ(⋅) has a closed graph, to ensure that it admits a fixed point.

Lemma 4.2: ϕ(⋅)\phi(\cdot)ϕ(⋅) has a closed graph.

Hard proof.

🤔Theorem 1. In FL, where utilities are continuous and any conical combination of utilities is convex, a core-stable predictor exists.

⚠️If we change d∈Pd\in Pd∈P to d∈B(θ,r)d\in\mathcal B(\theta, r)d∈B(θ,r), if the two condition still holds within a radius of rrr of every point. The conditions tend to be true in DNN of small rrr. Then the predictor is locally core-stable.

Computation of Core-Stable Predictor

There is efficient way to compute core-stable predictor.

It is optima of convex program:

maximize L(θ)=∑i∈[n]log⁡(ui(θ)) or ∏i∈[n]ui(θ)subject to θ∈P\text{maximize }\mathcal L(\theta)=\sum_{i\in[n]}\log(u_i(\theta))\text{ or }\prod_{i\in[n]}u_i(\theta)\\\text{subject to }\theta\in Pmaximize L(θ)=i∈[n]∑​log(ui​(θ)) or i∈[n]∏​ui​(θ)subject to θ∈P

The object reminds me of Nash Social Welfare😎

Utility of each agent is concave, thus above program is convex. Thus this program is concave maximization subject to convex constraint.

🤔Theorem 2. If uiu_iui​ is concave for all iii, then any predictor θ∗\theta^*θ∗ maximizes the convex program is core stable.

Proof by contradiction

∑i∈[n]ui(θ′)ui(θ∗)≤n.\sum_{i\in[n]}\frac{u_i(\theta')}{u_i(\theta^*)}\le n.i∈[n]∑​ui​(θ∗)ui​(θ′)​≤n.

If θ∗\theta^*θ∗ is not core-stable, there must exist θ′\theta'θ′ and subset SSS, s.t.

ui(θ′)≥n∣S∣ui(θ∗)u_i(\theta')\ge\frac{n}{|S|}u_i(\theta^*)ui​(θ′)≥∣S∣n​ui​(θ∗)

for all iii with at least one strict inequality.

Thus for any θ≠θ′\theta\neq\theta'θ=θ′,

∑i∈[n]ui(θ)ui(θ′)≥∑i∈Sui(θ)ui(θ′)>n/∣S∣⋅∣S∣=n,\sum_{i\in[n]}\frac{u_i(\theta)}{u_i(\theta')}\ge\sum_{i\in S}\frac{u_i(\theta)}{u_i(\theta')}\gt n/|S|\cdot|S|=n,i∈[n]∑​ui​(θ′)ui​(θ)​≥i∈S∑​ui​(θ′)ui​(θ)​>n/∣S∣⋅∣S∣=n,

admitting contradiction.

θ∗\theta^*θ∗ must be Pareto Optimal.

CoreFed

Stochastic Gradient Descent.

nnn finite samples {(xi,yi)}i∈[n]\{(x_i,y_i)\}_{i\in[n]}{(xi​,yi​)}i∈[n]​ drawn from data distribution P\mathcal PP, which constitute empirical distribution P^n\hat{\mathcal P}_nP^n​. The gradient can be expressed as an conical combination of the gradients of each group:

∇θ(θ)=∑i∈[n]∇θui(θ)ui(θ)=∑i∈[n]−∇θE(x,y)∼P^n(i)ℓ(fθ(x),y)Mi−E(x,y)∼P^n(i)ℓ(fθ(x),y)\nabla_\theta\mathcal(\theta)=\sum_{i\in[n]}\frac{\nabla_\theta u_i(\theta)}{u_i(\theta)}=\sum_{i\in[n]}\frac{-\nabla_\theta\mathbb E_{(x,y)\sim\hat{\mathcal P}_n^{(i)}}\ell(f_\theta(x),y)}{M_i-\mathbb E_{(x,y)\sim\hat{\mathcal P}_n^{(i)}}\ell(f_\theta(x),y)}∇θ​(θ)=i∈[n]∑​ui​(θ)∇θ​ui​(θ)​=i∈[n]∑​Mi​−E(x,y)∼P^n(i)​​ℓ(fθ​(x),y)−∇θ​E(x,y)∼P^n(i)​​ℓ(fθ​(x),y)​

For each group, reweight its gradients by (Mi−E(x,y)∼P^n(i)ℓ(fθ(x),y))−1(M_i-\mathbb E_{(x,y)\sim\hat{\mathcal P}_n^{(i)}}\ell(f_\theta(x),y))^{-1}(Mi​−E(x,y)∼P^n(i)​​ℓ(fθ​(x),y))−1 and then sum up to get the final weight update. This is base protocol.

In CoreFed the model weights are directly averaged and aggregated at each iteration.

Pseudo Code of CoreFed

Input: Number of clients KKK, number of rounds TTT, epochs EEE, learning rate η\etaη.

Output: Model weights θ⊤\theta^\topθ⊤

  1. For t←0t\gets0t←0 to T−1T-1T−1 do

    • Server selects a subset of KKK devices StS_tSt​

    • Server sends weights θt\theta^tθt to all selected devices

    • Each select device s∈Sts\in S_ts∈St​ updates θt\theta^tθt for EEE epochs of SGD with learning rate η\etaη to obtain new weights θˉst\bar\theta_s^tθˉst​

    • Each select devices s∈Sts\in S_ts∈St​ computes

      Δθst=θˉst−θt,Lst=1∣Ds∣∑i=1∣Ds∣ℓ(fθt(xs(i)),ys(i))\Delta\theta_s^t=\bar\theta_s^t-\theta^t,\\\mathcal L_s^t=\frac{1}{|\mathcal D_s|}\sum_{i=1}^{|\mathcal D_s|}\ell(f_{\theta^t}(x_s^{(i)}),y_s^{(i)})Δθst​=θˉst​−θt,Lst​=∣Ds​∣1​i=1∑∣Ds​∣​ℓ(fθt​(xs(i)​),ys(i)​)

      where Ds={(xs(i),ys(i)):i∈[∣Ds∣]}\mathcal D_s=\{(x_s^{(i)},y_s^{(i)}):i\in[|\mathcal D_s|]\}Ds​={(xs(i)​,ys(i)​):i∈[∣Ds​∣]} is the training dataset on device sss

    • Each selected device s∈Sts\in S_ts∈St​ sends Δθs\Delta \theta_sΔθs​ and Ls\mathcal L_sLs​ back to the server

    • Server updates θt+1\theta^{t+1}θt+1 following

      θt+1←θt+1∣St∣∑s∈StΔθstMs−Lst.\theta^{t+1}\gets\theta^t+\frac{1}{|S_t|}\sum_{s\in S_t}\frac{\Delta\theta_s^t}{M_s-\mathcal L_s^t}.θt+1←θt+∣St​∣1​s∈St​∑​Ms​−Lst​Δθst​​.

end

Core-Stability in Linear Regression and Classification with Logistic Regression

Utility function is concave.

uiu_iui​ is concave ⇔ℓ\Lrarr \ell⇔ℓ is convex

nnn finite samples {(xi,yi)}i∈[n]\{(x_i,y_i)\}_{i\in[n]}{(xi​,yi​)}i∈[n]​ drawn from data distribution P\mathcal PP, which constitute empirical distribution P^n\hat{\mathcal P}_nP^n​.

Linear Regression

fθ(x)=θ⊤xf_\theta(x)=\theta^\top xfθ​(x)=θ⊤x.

Regression loss E(x,y)∼P^n(i)ℓ(fθ(x),y)=E(x,y)∼P^n(i)(θ⊤x−y)2\mathbb E_{(x,y)\sim\hat{\mathcal P}_n^{(i)}}\ell(f_\theta(x),y)=\mathbb E_{(x,y)\sim\hat{\mathcal P}_n^{(i)}}(\theta^\top x-y)^2E(x,y)∼P^n(i)​​ℓ(fθ​(x),y)=E(x,y)∼P^n(i)​​(θ⊤x−y)2 would be convex in θ\thetaθ

🤔Lemma: CoreFed determines a core-stable predictor in a federated learning setting training linear regression

Classification with Logistic Regression

Given a classifier θ\thetaθ and a scalar c∈Rc\in Rc∈R, and agents iii’s loss is ℓi(θ,c)=∣∣θ∣∣22+α⋅∑i∈[n]log⁡(exp⁡(−yi(θ⊤xi+c))+1)\ell_i(\theta,c)=\frac{||\theta||_2}{2}+\alpha\cdot\sum_{i\in[n]}\log(\exp(-y_i(\theta^\top x_i+c))+1)ℓi​(θ,c)=2∣∣θ∣∣2​​+α⋅∑i∈[n]​log(exp(−yi​(θ⊤xi​+c))+1). ℓi\ell_iℓi​ is convex.

Thus, ui(θ,c)=Mi−ℓi(θ,c)u_i(\theta,c)=M_i-\ell_i(\theta,c)ui​(θ,c)=Mi​−ℓi​(θ,c) where Mi=arg⁡max⁡θ∈P,c∈R(ℓi(θ,c))M_i=\arg\max_{\theta\in P,c\in\mathbb R}(\ell_i(\theta,c))Mi​=argmaxθ∈P,c∈R​(ℓi​(θ,c)) is concave.

🤔Lemma: CoreFed determines a core-stable predictor in a federated learning setting training classification with logistic regression.

Approximate Core-Stability in DNN

entry.title: Efficient ReliK 2 Possible Parallelization Idea
entry.content:
Some ideas from Maximilian.

Recap Pseudo Code

Look at the Pseudo code again:

Input: KG K:⟨E,R,F⟩\mathcal K:\langle\mathcal E,\mathcal R,\mathcal F\rangleK:⟨E,R,F⟩, triple xhrt=(h,r,t)∈Fx_{hrt}=(h,r,t)\in\mathcal Fxhrt​=(h,r,t)∈F, embedding score function s:E×R×E→Rs:\mathcal E\times\mathcal R\times\mathcal E\to\mathbb Rs:E×R×E→R, sample size k∈Nk\in\mathbb Nk∈N

Output: ReliKLB(xhrt)ReliK_{LB}(x_{hrt})ReliKLB​(xhrt​) or ReliKApx(xhrt)ReliK_{Apx}(x_{hrt})ReliKApx​(xhrt​)

  1. SH←S_H\getsSH​← sample kkk triples from N−(h)\mathcal N^-(h)N−(h); ST←S_T\getsST​← sample kkk triples from N−(t)N^-(t)N−(t).

  2. rankH←1rank_H\gets1rankH​←1; rankT←1rank_T\gets1rankT​←1

  3. for xh′r′t′∈SH∪STx_{h'r't'}\in S_H\cup S_Txh′r′t′​∈SH​∪ST​ do

    • If s(xhrt)≤s(xh′r′t′)s(x_{hrt})\le s(x_{h'r't'})s(xhrt​)≤s(xh′r′t′​) then

      • if h′=hh'=hh′=h then

        rankH←rankH+1rank_H\gets rank_H+1rankH​←rankH​+1

      • if t′=tt'=tt′=t then

        rankT←rankT+1rank_T\gets rank_T+1rankT​←rankT​+1

  4. return 12(1rankH+∣N−(h)∣−∣SH∣+1rankT+∣N−(t)∣−∣ST∣)\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{1}{rank_H+|\mathcal N^-(h)|-|S_H|}+\frac{1}{rank_T+|\mathcal N^-(t)|-|S_T|}\right)21​(rankH​+∣N−(h)∣−∣SH​∣1​+rankT​+∣N−(t)∣−∣ST​∣1​) for ReliKLBReliK_{LB}ReliKLB​

    or 12(1rankHN−(h)∣SH∣+1rankTN−(t)∣ST∣)\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{1}{rank_H\frac{\mathcal N^-(h)}{|S_H|}}+\frac{1}{rank_T\frac{\mathcal N^-(t)}{|S_T|}}\right)21​(rankH​∣SH​∣N−(h)​1​+rankT​∣ST​∣N−(t)​1​) for ReliKApxReliK_{Apx}ReliKApx​

Ideas for Parallelization

Idea 1 Parallel Sampling

Sampling the negative sets SHS_HSH​ and STS_TST​ can be done in parallel for both head and tail entities. GPU-based libraries like PyTorch can handle large-scale sampling efficiently on GPUs.

I will think about it.

Idea 2 Rank Update

For each sampled triple xh′r′t′x_{h'r't'}xh′r′t′​, it can be parallelized across all samples in SH∪STS_H\cup S_TSH​∪ST​. For-parallel

GPUs are very efficient at handling this kind of parallel computation, especially with batched matrix operations.

✅I will be working on this.

Will there be some write-after-write or read-after-write issues? Should I add some write-lock?

entry.title: 丹麦语 DU 3.3 4 Højskoler
entry.content:
气死了！完整的笔记被覆盖掉了😡

Nyt ordforråd om højskoler og fællesskaber

højskole “休闲中学”，丹麦专有的特殊的学校，没有考试和入学要求，通常是文理中学毕业的学生 gap year 的去处。

fællesskab -et, -er, -erne 社区

halvanden 一又二分之一

skynde -r, -de, -t 匆忙

netværk et, - eller -er, -ene eller -erne 网络

emne -t, -r, -rne 主题

hverken … eller … 既不……也不……

adgangskrav 入学要求

idræt -ten, -ter, -terne 体育

区分 tror, synes, tænke

  • tror：表示相信或猜测，基于不确定的事实或推测。

  • synes：表示个人的主观看法或感受，通常用于表达意见。

  • tænke：表示思考的过程，可以是计划、反思或想念。

bl.a. 例如

vælge -r, valgte, valgt 选择

Sætningskløvninger

表示强调句子中的某一个成分，可以使用“分局” sætningskløvninger

Der-kløvninger

ved ubekendt subjekt: Der er …, der …

  • Der er mig, der spiser.
  • Der er ham, der er chef.

ved ubekendt objekt: Der var …, …

  • Der var mange ting, man skulle tjekke.
  • Der var nogle af kollegerne, han var glad for.

Spørgende sætninger: Er der …, der …

  • Er der er nogen af jer, der møder kl. 8?
  • Er der en af lederne, der kommer til mødet?

Det-kløvninger

fremhævet subjekt: Det er …, der …

fremhævet objekt: Det er …, S + V

fremhævet adverbial datid: Det var …, S + V

spørgsmål med hv-ord: Hvem er det, der …

spørgsmål med hv-ord datid: hv-ord var det, …

spørgsmål uden hv-ord: Er det …, der …

Læseforståelse

阅读理解很难，大概是讲丹麦公共教育的历史和丹麦农民合作社的历史。

Højskolebevægelsen

højskolebevægelsen 高中运动（19 世纪中叶基于 N. F. S. Grundtvig 关于公共教育和民族社区的思想而兴起的民众运动 ）

hovedmand -en, …mænd, …mændene 关键人物，主要人物

mene -r, mente, ment 认为

på den tid 当时

teoretisk -, -e 理论的

almindelig -t, -e 普通的，一般的，普遍的

  • almindelig mennesker 普通人
  • almindelige familier 普通家庭

hver anden dag 每隔一天

at hjælpe til i marken 帮忙干农活

udenadslære -n 死记硬背

streng disciplin 严格的纪律

streng -t, -e | -ere, -est 严格的，霸道的，僵化的，一刀切的

Folkeoplysning og almen dannelse

almen -t, -e 整体的，适用大多数人的

folkeoplysning -en 公共教育

kundskab -en, -er, -erne 知识

daglig -t, -e 日常

betydning -en, -er, -erne 意义

elev -en, -er, -erne 中小学生，学徒

at have behov for 需要

Andelsbevægelsen

andelsbevægelse -n, -r, -rne 合作社运动

opstå -r, opstod, -et 出现

i løbet af 在……期间

oprette -r, -de, -t 创建

andelsforening -en, -er, -erne 合作社

forening -en, -er, -erne 协会

Fællesskabet og samarbejdet

bonde -n, bønder, bønderne 农民

kræve -r, -de, -t 要求
